reviewText:
Rating: 9/10, better than Bioshock Infinite.
Good gameplay
Badass swordplay
Solid Story
Good graphics and art direction
Funny dialogue
The makers of Hard Rest (Flying Wild Hog) are responsible for this excellent re imagining of Shadow Warrior. I played very little of the original Shadow Warrior, but it is basically an asian duke-nukem. Maze like level layouts, funny one liners, puzzles, culture references, all that sorta ♥♥♥♥. Now the reboot here is a lot different. The levels are less maze like and more straight forward, like newer fps games. There is some backtracking once and awhile, but in my opinion I didn't mind it. You can carry all of the guns you get and there are secrets and you fight hordes of enemies, no cover shooting at all. Health packs and everything too. Some minor character elements are still there but with a lot that was added to it. There is still some funny one liners and such, dont worry. Also they added a good story with good writing. Now the first part to cover is the gameplay.

The gameplay consists of navigating Japenese inspired levels, doing small objects, and shooting and slicing up hordes of enemies. You have your health and stamina bar. Sprinting and a sort of ninja/dodge/dash with a press of the shift key and either (w a s d). The main focus in this game is the melee combat, which is amazing. A mix of light and heavy attacks, with double presses of either (w a s d). It is a very fluid and satisfying combat system all the way to the end. The enemies also slice up into little gibs, its cool as hell! The guns in the start are a tad underwhelming in the beginning, but it takes upgrades for those guns to make them more enjoyable. There is an upgrade system as well. One tier for powers, another for guns, and a last one for skills. The powers are a double tap (w a s d) right mouse button mechanic, for example self healing or using a force push ability. These use Ki crystals to upgrade by the way. Guns are for what you expect, upgrading your pistol, machine gun, cross bow and other guns with money. Skills are a mix of katana abilities and buffs for health, and killing demons and such, skills upgrade with karma, which you get by fighting enemies and secret karma stashes.

The graphics are also amazing in this. I am using a Nivida GeForce GTX 770 with this game, Ultra, FXAA on, and it is nice looking. From vast mountains, bamboo trees, ponds, old Japanese architecture, huge temples, and towns. Nice lighting, textures and overall design. Only thing that could have had a bit more work is the faces of the people, they look sorta bad but they work. There is also some amazing cinematics, sort of like a visual moving novel. They tie into the story with the characters in it.

The last part I want to go over is the story, its good. Its about a Japanese man named Lo Wang, a bodyguard for a corporation called Zilla Enterprises. Lo Wang is tasked to retrieve a sword called the Nobistura Kage for his boss Orochi Zilla. All hell breaks loose and the sword is taken by a demon like ghost. And demons rain all through Japan and murder everyone. You then are met with a demon entity named Hoji. Which he tells you the end of the world is because of the Nobistura Kage. There is a mix of Japanese spirit world lore in this too, and surprisingly an interesting and captivating story for a shooter like this.

Now should you buy this game? Yeah, if you like hack and slash games with an old/new school fps twist with a good story. There are not very many games that are fps and have hack and slash elements: and its solid. I would even say I enjoyed this game more than a triple A title like Bioshock Infinite.
voteText: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me just add my positive review to the pile...

Frankly I'm surprised the metacritic rating is so low for Shadow Warrior. It's a well-polished game with very nice graphics, good game-play, interesting combat that rewards not spamming the same technique all the time, has a really nice and emotionally involving story (that ending!), includes Easter eggs referring to the original game for nostalgia (and refers to other popular games too), and it somehow balances a line between being ludicrously cheesy (try to keep count of how many Wang puns there are, or better yet: take a drink every time there is a Wang joke!) and being somewhat self-deprecating because they know how stupid it is, but for Shadow Warrior to not have Wang jokes and over the top cliche'd settings would just not be Shadow Warrior.

This is how you breathe new life into a game franchise. Other devs should take notes on this game, because there's a lot of childhood favourites that I would like to see get this kind of treatment.

Edit: I bought the special edition because I love Hotline Miami, and really it wasn't worth the extra money, even on sale. I'm not sure what I expected with that promo sword, but it's just not worth it. Definitely buy the standard edition.

10/10 would play with Wang again (hur hur hur).

reviewText:
A very fun, very gruesome fps. If you have ever wanted to play with a sword in an fps game this is probably your best choice.

I primarily enjoyed using my sword whenever possible, there are a variety of attacks you can do with it including a ranged one so you can almost always complete an entire fight with it without much trouble.   The guns are all upgrade-able with a variety of improvements and utility upgrades,  the ability to dual wield on the smg or explosive bolts for the crossbow are two of my favorites.  It has very satisfying though not overly difficult combat, that managed to keep me engaged throughout the 10 hour campaign.

The artstyle and graphics are good.  Nothing really sticks out about them besides the fact that you can slash anything that can explode with your sword and see the results.  There are enough different enemies to prevent you from feeling like you are doing the same fight over and over.  You can blow limbs or cut your enemies in half, which results in blood everywhere and is one of the most enjoyable parts of the game.

The story is coherent and entertaining, while the player cracks jokes at every opportunity he can, usually about his name.

Overall I had a lot of fun with this game and would love to see more games like this.  The campaign didn't feel too long or too short, and I think it would be re-playable enough for another run.  It's very hard these days to find a satisfying fps these days, but at least we have this one.

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior เป็นเกมแนว Action-FPS ที่คาดว่าจะได้ประสบการณ์ใหม่ๆ ที่ FPS เกมอื่นไม่มีอยู่เยอะอยู่ ถึงแม้อารมณ์บางช่วงจะมีส่วนคล้าย เกมเดินยิงในตำนานกับมอนสเตอร์นับแสนแบบ Serious Sam ก็ตาม ภาคนี้เป็นภาครีบูท โดยเราจะรับบทเป็น Lo Wang ได้รับภารกิจไปตามหาดาบ Nobitsura Kage ซึ่งเป็นที่ต้องการมากมายตั้งแต่มนุษย์ ยันปิศาจ เป็นเกม FPS ที่ไม่จำกัดการเก็บอาวุธโดย พระเอกของเราจะเก็บอาวุธไว้ในตูดเหมือน ลุงแซม ให้ใช้ยันเลข 1 ถึงเลข 9 เลยที่เดียวตอนเปลี่ยน แต่ คาตะนะ อาวุธชิ้นแรก ก็เป็นตัวชูโรงของเกมนี้เลยก็ว่าได้
-ในเกมมีคนให้สับ ยัน ปิศาจ ละเอียดมากสามารถตัดศพได้ด้วย ซึ่งถ้ามันเละ ก็จะเห็น ตับ ไต้ ไส้ พุง กระเพราะ อ่าาห์ เลือดสาด สะใจ ขาโหดเลยทีเดียว
-บรรยกาศในเกม มีตั้งแต่สไตล์ญี่ปุ่น ไปจนถึงสไตล์แบบหนังแอ๊คชั่น
-มีการอัพสกิล อัพอาวุธ ของตัวละคร ซึ่งก็ทำได้น่าสนใจ เลือกใช้ตามความถนัดได้เลย
-Boss Fight ตัวใหญ่จุงกระเบย สู้แต่ละที เหมือนจะมันส์ แต่ก็ไม่มันส์แหะ (ตกลงยังไง)
-กราฟฟิค ชวนหลงไหล เลือกปรับได้เยอะอยู่ ดนตรีประกอบทำได้เหมาะสมมาก
---------------------------------------------------------สรุป------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText: On sale for 1€, this was probably the best deal I've ever made. One of the most fun FPS I've ever played (especially in the recent flood of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ CoD clones). Imagine the classic Shadow Warrior mixed with Bulletstorm and some simple character development. Fun melee combat + great visuals + tons of humour!\n\nThe only problem is optimization, in some areas the performance will drop, a lot - especially with reflections turned on. But most of the time it's fine.

reviewText: I'll be honest, this is a great game. All in all, a great effort. And if these developers were the same behind Duke Nukem Forever, it wouldn't have gotten all the bashing it did.

reviewText: Alright, the only reason why I bought this game was because it was 90% off ($3.99) during the holiday sale, and it looked interesting based on the screenshots. I wasn't expecting much. However, this game completely took me by surprise and it was a fantastic journey from start to finish. The combat is deliciously gorey with very intereting ways to pull off special attacks. (By the way, do not play this on a controller - keyboard and mouse is the way to go in order to pull off special moves with ease.) There are RPG elements in which you spend different points to upgrade your weapons and learn new skills. The game is over-the-top and the humor is great - in particular the banter between the two protagonists. The story was surprisingly poignant and the artwork in the cutscenes was simply beautiful. The in-game graphics are nice, but nothing too special, especially the character models which look blocky and low res. Some of the environments are quite pleasing to the eye though. In short I highly recommend this game, and do not mess with the Wang.

reviewText: Flying Wild Hog has topped their previous game, Hard Reset, in nearly every respect with Shadow Warrior. A myriad of beautiful environments, crazy but balanced and innovative combat, and a smoother difficulty curve prove that the Polish studio has graphical, level and gameplay design talent to spare.Shadow Warrior is top-notch action entertainment. It doesn't matter whether or not it is a remake.This game has a good variety of unlocks and enough challenges to make completionists feel as if they got their money’s worth.It's fast, old school and with tons of blood. Don’t miss this one.

reviewText: The Wang way\n\nAs with Flying Wild Hog’s previous title, Hard Reset (great, 4/5) SHADOW WARRIOR is a whole lot of riotous fun. Like it’s predecessor, it’s an old-school shooter, but with SW we get the added fun of melee combat. And that’s basically what SW is all about: katana mayhem. It also shares much of the mechanics and gameplay tropes of the earlier game, and that’s all to the good as well. It differs from Hard Reset in some areas, however, most notably with the variety of weapons and the more conventional upgrade system and skills tree. There’s also a stronger story, although it is a tad incoherent at times. There are some very cool cutscenes, but they’re used sparsely and never intrude but do help to flesh out the story. And there’s also plenty of amusing, deliberately cheesy, dialogue to enjoy. Graphically, SW is one of the most stunning games I’ve come across, and it also delivers some impressive physics. It’s not open world, as is de rigueur these days, but its linearity keeps the story, and the game progression, on the rails and never detracts from the fun. Hugely enjoyable and highly recommended. 4/5

reviewText:
Easily a top contender for GotY.
A very bold reimagining of a classic shooter, Shadow Warrior accomplishes what it sets out to achieve with spot-on accuracy. Fast paced retro action, a good story, great humor, a solid upgrade system, encouragement for world exploration and possibly the most dynamic dismemberment system I've seen.
What's not so great I'd have to say would be hit-detection, you can unload an entire magazine on somebodies face but sometimes the game won't register the hits, so you do no damage, waste ammo and look like an idiot. Thankfully this isn't a frequent occurance so when it does happen it doesn't ruin too much.
So until I play more of it and get more information in order to write a proper review let me say this: Shadow Warrior is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, get it.

reviewText:
This game blew me away, not only does the game look gorgeous, have a great soundtrack and solid level design, it also has some of the best first person melee combat out there. The swordplay is so fun and satisfying that I almost solely used the katana for the whole game.
There are also several chi powers and a whole arsenal of unique guns each with even more unique and insane upgrades.
While the boss fights could sometimes grow tedious on insane dificulty they didn't feel out of place at all.
Even if the story is relatively simple the whole time i felt compelled to find out more and continue my quest.
But the most surprising thing about this game is that it managed to make me tear up a bit at the end.

Overall this is a great game that felt very rewarding and sometimes mildly frustrating on insane dificulty.

reviewText:
What a solid product we have here. Pretty much loved it from start to finish.

*Some of the best first person melee combat out there
*Extremely vivid visuals the entire campaign
*Honestly funny, yet immature dialog. Hoji cracks me up.
*The devs recently updated the game with 64bit and DX11 support, which made the game run like a dream for me.
*Very lengthy campaign with a good variety of environments, enemies, equipment, abilities, etc.
*Retro FPS sensibilities that are sorely lacking in today's genre.
*A ninja star to a semi-truck's windshield makes the whole damn thing explode.
*Easily satiates anyone's Wang quotient.

I can't think of many gripes. I suppose some basic multiplayer or coop modes would have been nice. It does have a New Game + mode, should you want to earn every upgrade for Wang that you couldnt afford the first time through. After the new patch, the only technical issue I had was the cutscenes, which are rare, all played only from my center speaker on my 5.1 setup.

Considering how insanely cheap this game is on sale, I insist that every steam user own it. The devs deserve more attention for this one.

reviewText:
Might contain spoilers. WILL contain parentheses (a lot).

When this came out I was furious that someone had the nerve to call a game Shadow Warrior, exactly the same as the 1997 3D Realms title (as you can probably tell from that attitude, I loved that game as a kid). As the negative emotions got weaker (and the price lower) I decided to give it a try and I have to say it does its name justice. The many references to the original game didn't feel forced (and weren't overdone), and paired with modern engine and eyecandy, it was pretty damn awesome. There were some little things mostly associated with it being a 2013 game that I didn't like (certain gameplay mechanics, but mostly a number of things too small to mention), but overall I'd give this like 9/10 if I were to use numbers.

Pros:
+ Very good melee combat system. The special moves (including a ranged attack) make the sword a viable and even preferrable weapon for most of the game.
+ Good engine. Haven't had any problems with hit detection or gamebreaking glitches.
+ Nice aesthetics overall. I really liked the 2D cutscenes.
+ Different sorts of environment from traditional japanese to modern industrial, topped with some surreal sky landscapes, much like the original game.
+ Plentiful throwbacks to the original 1997 Shadow Warrior (either references or parts of SW1997 levels in secrets).

Cons:
- A little too linear level design in places. A secret" is something you find if you wander more than ten feet off the beaten path.
- Unentertaining bosses. I only played on Normal difficulty so far so this might not be objective
recommended: it just takes forever to take them down because of the tedious weak spots.\n- Most ranged weapons felt meh. Like

reviewText: Shadow Warrior utilizes beautiful visuals, sound, and controller prowess. The seamless change from fire arm to melee combat coupled with the rewarding levelling up system which allows you to personalize your play style leaves you feeling satisfied. I was never familiar of the original Shadow Warrior however I think long-time fans will appreciate its subtly nods to its past. The voice work is also of high quality. If you are looking for a fun single player FPS action oriented campaign. I implore you to check this game out, I am already looking forward to the sequel which will feature co op. Have fun slaying demons and otherworldly horrors in the silly game.\n\nMake peace before Lo Wang cuts you to pieces ~

reviewText:
This game is fun to play...for a short while.  After the first few chapters, you'll realize that you've seen just about everything the game has to offer.  The combat is boring once you come to understand that you'll be fighting the same enemies over and over and over.  It's difficult to take a strategic approach to the combat as most foes simply materialize out of thin air.  The time and place for encounters are also predictable.  If you find a large, unoccupied room, expect the enemies to start materializing any second.

The developers could have knocked this one out of the park.  The weapons are fun to use and the special powers are nice also.  It's just the variation that is lacking.

If the price was around $5, it would be worth a look.

reviewText:
I recently finished Shadow Warrior as it went on sale a couple weeks ago and as I was already highly interested in the game by the humoristic moments they showed in the trailers I decided to finally get it.

Now having finished the game I was quite impressed by the amount of quality they managed to put into it, while the game is pretty linear it does provide you with a pretty lovely and rather comedic story combined with some great action from slashing demon with your katana or just blasting their heads off with an a four barrel shotgun.

The graphics of the game were also quite nice to look at, not to say they were the best but there were moments that I was baffled by the quality of the beautiful scenery that made me even stand still and just look around to then kill a couple more waves of demons.

The gameplay was pretty fast paced with enough breathing room in between to prepare yourself for the next battle or for more story development.

In general the gameplay was quite good and I really liked the comedy factor brought into the story, together with that the story was pretty properly buildup and combined with really great action I have to say that I really did enjoy playing this game.

All in all this game sure was fun to play!


Overall Score: 9/10
voteText: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So many great memories with the first shadow warrior, many years ago, heh.
Well, putting my nostalgia away i will try to make a short review on this one.
They wanted to create something modern, but not very modern.
They wanted to create something classic, but not that classic.
Did they achieve their goal? Hell Yea
This wasn't meant to be something very unique, not at all, they wanted to make a modern sequel to the original game, they've done it well.
Graphics, damn good.
Gameplay, even more damn good.
Combat system, awesome.
You have a katana, and you have lots of weapons (just like in the old one), but to be honest, who would play with fire weapons in a game where you have a melee weapon? Heh. But it's nice they've added them. I didn't use them too much, only to fight bosses. I didn't use fire weapons to kill flying demons, i was just throwing my katana.
The feeling when you slice a demon.. is priceless.
It has around 10 hours of gameplay,
Actually, i even forgot that i had the sledgehammer from Serious Sam 3, and other nice melee weapons, since i've got the special edition, aaaand, i've finished the game. I really got caught up by it.
I really recommend this to any Shadow Warrior 3D Fan, or to any nostalgic guy. This game is really worth the money. I am very happy with this one, and i am waiting for future sequels.

reviewText:
Hold Any Key to Skip!

Finished this on Hard.  Insane will have to wait.  Shadow Warrior while possessing kick ♥♥♥ combat mechanics is too long and much like Hard Reset the desire to continue in EX mode wanes.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

The boss fights are indeed memorable but not pleasantly.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

For a team of developers on the precipice of delivering an entire package, their boss fights are an exercise in tedium having you running around an arena for ammo like a dog looking for a hydrant on which to lift its leg to relieve itself.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

The environments are beautiful and an array of graphical options await.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Hard Reset players will notice environmental hazards to electrify enemies carried forth as well as their sound effects and physics.  Additional environmental hazards have been added as well that fit the inherent theme.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Non rendered and drawn cut scenes follow in the footsteps of Hard Reset as well.  They're low budget but serve their purpose.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Secrets abound and if that's what gets you off then you're well taken care of.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Weapons are a mixed bag.  The shotgun is laughable however every other weapon is well done.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Certain enemies will unwillingly donate their organs to you so you can use them against their fellow hordes.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Weapon upgrades are available at any time given you've acquired enough coin as are Katana abilities which can be acquired via an alternate currency.

Hold Any Key to Skip!

Shadow Warrior is a kick ♥♥♥ game and one you most definitely want to play but please do remember;  Hold Any Key to Skip!

reviewText:
A remake for 1990s classic Shadow Warrior. This game came out of the bushes and all that I  thought about it was going to be no more than more or less okey made successor for some game fossil, but after reading couple of reviews and watching gameplays, I decided to add this to my collection.
Shadow Warrior showed me how these prejudices can be anything but right. The game is absolutly magnificent!! The easily mastered mixture of melee and long ranged fighting works better than any game I've played and numerous fighting moves picked from different skill trees quarantee the most entertaining fast, upbeat battles. So, the fighting is smooth and there is a lot of it: tens, even hundreds of enemies fall during one map, filled with several secret places to search for, just like in the original Shadow Warriror, where the game keeps refering to.
As for the plot and characters, they are well written - the storyline though is quite typical, but they are the characters which in my opinion hit into the jackpot! Player playes Long Wang, who is an exceptional anti-hero, followed by a companion and sidekick: the demon Hoji, and these two rascals form a couple whose epic conversations I used to crack up so many times.
Shadow Warrior is not only one of the biggest surprices of 2013, but also one of the best games in 2013. In addition IMO it's one of the best games ever! So whether you were or not a fan of last milleniums Shadow Warrior, I'm definitely going to recommend to check this out!

reviewText: How in the hell did it take so long for me to discover this gem?! If you are a fan of FPS games like Serious Sam, Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D etc... then you absolutely MUST buy this game. Sure there are several guns to choose from and plenty of mayhem to be had with demonic-like powers but the real fun IMO comes with the swordplay. The swordplay mechanics are absolutely fantastic and blast to play. There is nothing quite as satisfying as slicing a demon apart limb by limb then finishing him off with a good ol' fashioned decapitation. I could literally run through the entire game with my sword out and not feel the need to pull out a gun. It's a blast!\n\nThe level's are very linear with a few collectibles and secrets" scattered about along with crystals that help you upgrade your character. They were never really hard for me to find so I am sure you won't have any trouble either. There is usually a boss of some sort at the end of each level as well
date:
they aren't all that hard and I recommend using a  machine gun or Launcher on them as to keep distance from the melee attacks. Your character also has a talent tree of sorts which you can use the Crystals to pick whichever talent upgrade you want. You can also earn and find money and ammo via boxes or kills (think Bioshock or Farcry) and use the money on upgrades for your weapons. You can save at any point as well which I encourage you to do because instant deaths can happen and it can be frustrating.

I feel I also need to say something about our main character (not much but something). He is a fairly likable Asian man with cheesy one-liners ala' Duke Nukem or Serious Sam which are delivered at tense moments to lighten the mood. They made more sense in those games because those protaganists are more big burly badasses but Lo Wang is more of an assassin so it didn't really fit for me. It still is not bad to watch though.

All in all if you are a fan of Ninja's
hoursPlayed:
Samurai swords or dismembering demons pick this gem up (8$ on sale sometimes!).

-Casey
"

reviewText: Despite its old-school aspect Shadow Warrior manage to add something different to the FPS genre: swordplay! Drop your gun and draw your katana! A real warrior should rely on his melee weapon and not on his long range weapons. The humor in Shadow Warrior is full of pop culture content! Don't take this game too seriously! This game was made for pure enjoyment! If you want more old-school action FPS after Serious Sam BFE pick this one up! The game doesn't include multiplayer but don't worry. For 40$ you will get at least 15 hours of gameplay if you crank up the difficulty to the maximum. In the FPS field this game lenght is almost inexistant. Boss fights are memorable as they are humongous. Don't forget to add up replayability as you can unlock more skills more powers!\n\nRating: A-

reviewText: The further and further I get into the game, recommending it gets harder. The combat is fantastic, combining swordplay and faceshooting by rewarding the player for killing groups of enemies in convoluted, awesome fashions. Lighting a group of enemies on fire and then decapitating them all is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome! However, around hour five is when things start sliding into ♥♥♥♥♥ville, because that's when the enemies with glowing weak spots appear to destroy the momentum by being a trope of gaming that sucks. Hour ten is when the writing shines, and by that I mean the game overstays its welcome while trying to wrap up its overwritten, boring story with nothing new to offer. It's still better than the original by a wide margin!

reviewText:
A shining example of a First Person Shooter done right.
No wee-wee-spunk-gargle here.

All the weapons feel diferent, and no one of them seems ultimately better than another. They all have a good impact as well. And the sword? I pretty much used the sword 99% of the time my first playthrough. It's fantastic. Slice through enemy demons spraying their blood and body parts everywhere. I hear demon blood is good for your skin, so don't feel bad being covered in it.

Great game. If you're not willing to pay full price, get it on sale. Not only is the action good but it's funny, and upholds the inappropriateness of the original. The level designs are good as well.
I enjoyed it from start to finish.

reviewText:
A extremely fun game with beautiful graphics, atmosphere and detailed world. One of the best games I have played in a long time.

The combat is so much fun, slashing and destroying with your katana and powers, you have the ability to destroy almost everything around you. I prefer mostly using the katana, I find it much more fun than using guns which almost feel pointless as they don't seem as strong, effective or fun as the katana.

It has quite a good story line with amusing dialogue from Wang, upgradable weapons, powers and skills and hidden things to find for those who take the time to explore thoroughly.

The only thing I didn't like is that you have to double tap a direction then hold and release lmb or rmb to use a katana ability or power which makes it feel a bit slow to execute.

This game is a definite must play  I give it a rating of 8/10.

reviewText:
I have enjoyed this game WAY more than any other single player FPS I have played. The sheer amount of power you feel while playing as Lo Wang is just great.

There's a lot of nuance to its experience that most reviewers fail to mention. Now maybe it's better if you are surprised by them once you play the game;
however...IF you're on the fence and want to know what makes this game STAND OUT..., THEN keep reading.
**ONE story-related SPOILER AHEAD, but it is something you find out in the first chapter**
(it's the 3rd '+')
******************
***************
************
*********
******
****
**
*
+GREAT for relieving stress
+can chop off enemy's leg just to watch him hop around and grab his leg in pain
(each enemy is sliced n' diced exactly how it should be, with directional slices)
+have this 'spirit' ally with you & it talks to you throughout the game (with comedic results)
+/- it's an arena shooter, meaning you will kill a group of enemies, then explore/relax until you run into the next batch
+can heal yourself with a magical skill (heals up to 60% of your max hp, but can be upgraded to more)
- a few of the chapters are too long IMO (3 or 4 chapters took ≈2 hrs to complete)
- no co-op or multi-player
+are secret items to collect in every level
+well balanced enemies/combat
+can simultaneously do magic in one hand and use weapon in the other. oh yeah!

20-23 hours to complete (story mode)
for most people, but took me 25 hrs. in-game time



Edit 1:fixed typos
Edit 2: After beating the game, I edited the line about a few of the chapters [being] too long..."
Edit 3: added approx. time to complete campaign
Edit 4: took out "I love this game!" so you don't think I'm totally biased. & added more explanation of the 'slicing and dicing' mechanics of this game under the pros & cons section"

reviewText:
Very entertaining ninjaish hack 'N' slash FPS. The combat system is great and fast paced with lots of combos and different skills/abilities to use (including different powers, perks and badass wep attachments :) ).  Melee combat/swordplay is extremely rewarding and brutal so that slicing through tons of enemies feels very good indeed.

There are lots of guns to use aswell, which mainly have a fairly nice gunfeel, but could be improved at some parts.  The game's combat mechanics are great and diverse, including the Ki system that is a bit familiar to Bioshock's Plasmid and Vigor systems. I would also recommend trying macros with this game:).

At the top of all, the game also looks very nice and has nice music, good humor (yet a bit sexist at some points) and a suprisingly well written story.  It's also pretty lenghty for an indie game.

I would very much recommend Shadow Warrior to anyone who loves some good old fps and hack 'n' slash action.

reviewText:
This game has so much to offer.  I will point out the only thing that could have made it better for me is a few additional monster types, however, the way the game is setup, you can dispose of them in many different ways and I can see where each enemy would involve a lot of animations and coding.  The enemies exhibit a good of moves that change the pace around and are very detailed, as is the whole game really.

I took as many screenshots in this game as I did with games like STALKER and METRO because I was just in awe.  It also features a very unique to FPS system of being able to upgrade your weapons as well as passive and active abilities and sword attacks that all have there own relation to dispatching various enemies.  The story is fun but features a great skip scene option for those of us that don't wish to watch it all.

The developers put their heart and soul into this game, it is fun, exciting, beautiful and unique.  A rare combination to find these days.  I rate it a 95%.

reviewText:
This game is a really hard to explain... It is a sort of hack'n'slash / first person shooter. All the levels are way more beautiful then I thought they would be. The gameplay feels solid, the tone is serious while keeping it comedic. It has a bunch of references to the first shadow warrior that I played a bit back when I was younger such as almost naked pixel girls bathing  scattered through the land and rabbits that wont stop ****ing. They give you a lot of options to customize the game, Almost everything in the environment is intractable and can be destroyed and I have yet to find any problems or bugs other than the frame rate problem that is noted below.

Before buying this game there are some things you should note:
1. The game somewhat makes fun of chinese culture. Not as much as the first one though.
2. It is somewhat of a gore fest as you chop people in half with your katana.
3. MOST IMPORTANT this game has frame rate issues. I tend to think my PC is fairly good. It can run most games at a solid 60fps and if not turning of shadows or vsync would help. But no matter what I do I cant get this game to run any higher than 30~45fps. After looking around it seems you need a somewhat beast computer to make it run smoothly due to some issue I didn't look into much. So if you have a Xbone or PS4 I would recommend buying it on one or the other, But if you have a good PC go for it.

reviewText:
A incredible fun game, with a lot of focus on Sword fighting and just gernerally murdering stuff.
You get a Katana as your first weapon, and i personally found it to be the most fun to use. You get a lot of the normal old-school FPS weapons (SMG, Pistol, Rocket launcher, Crossbow etc.) But they all felt very stiff. But they're not the interesting part of this gime.

You have 3 things you can upgrade, your skills, powers, and weapons. Skils are for stuf like more health, faster run speed, new katana abilities, Something that a normal person would be able to develop generally. Then there is the powers. 4 different in total. They are all executed by doing a movement key twice then right-click (Movement key twice + left click is for the katana skills). This might seem difficult at first, but it actually works really well, and gives you easy access to all your abilities. My favorite personally, was the flux. By Pressing S twice, and then right-click, you would charge up your first. When you released right-click, it would throw a long line into the ground, that would lift enemies up in the air for several seconds. Its amazing using the flux, then blowing someones head off with a shotgun.

The enemies are a bit weird though.

They're mostly Demons.

Not a concept i enjoyed too much, but you find a few human enemies in some sections too. The demons all have specific abilities, and there are major and minor.

The minor are the ones you might be able to slash to pieces in one or few hits, while the major can take a while to kill.
Of the minor demons, we have your usual run and hit you zombie. The radioactive that explode when you get near or shoot them. The shielders and the invisibles.

The shielders has to be the enemy i dreaded the most, not only do they block your attacks, they keep looking in your direction and you have to either throw them down, or hit the shield until it breaks. It can take a while and really breaks the flow of the game, when you're spinning around and killing litearlly everybody around you, except for them.

Of the major enemies, there are 3: The Warlord, The Charger, and the Shaman. The major are a bit more interesting, so i'll talk about them.

The shaman will summon and resurrect nearby enemies, and just keep doing this until you kill him. After hes around halfway dead, he will create a green unbreakable barrier, and summon some skeletons that flash with green colors. After you kill the skeletons, the shield breaks and you can finish him off.

The Warlord will enrage nearby eneies (Which is, make them darker, and make them more powerful. Enemies can also be enraged if you use abilities or powers near them, even if there isin't a warlord there) He will also try to smash you, a lot. So every few seconds, he will throw a really fast red line, and if you touch it, he will pull you to him, and he will smash the ground.

The final one is the charger. Hes simple, and kind of boring to be honest. He will charge you, you evade it near a wall. He hits the wall. You slice his back a few times. Rinse and repeat. It just takes so long to kill these guys, that the fun quickly dies from fighting them.

But of all enemies, the most interesting one is the bosses. There are a total of 3 Demon bosses, and they're all amazing to fight. They're HUGE, and the shadow realm is just right-out eyecandy. They are all very Zelda-ish, and its very fun.

All in all, if you have ever played Red steel 1 or 2, and enjoyed it. Or just want to enjoy a throwback to the old FPS with a mix of very interesting sword fighting, you should pick this game up.

9/10

26 Apr 2015 (21h):
It's been a while since I added something to this review. In the meantime I've finished the game on normal, and have started over on Insane up to and including the first boss battle.
I think they could've made the skills a little more interesting, but it's only really starting to bother me a third into my second playthrough ... so that's just a replayability issue. reviewText:
Very entertaining ninjaish hack 'N' slash FPS. The combat system is great and fast paced with lots of combos and different skills/abilities to use (including different powers, perks and badass wep attachments :) ).  Melee combat/swordplay is extremely rewarding and brutal so that slicing through tons of enemies feels very good indeed.

There are lots of guns to use aswell, which mainly have a fairly nice gunfeel, but could be improved at some parts.  The game's combat mechanics are great and diverse, including the Ki system that is a bit familiar to Bioshock's Plasmid and Vigor systems. I would also recommend trying macros with this game:).

At the top of all, the game also looks very nice and has nice music, good humor (yet a bit sexist at some points) and a suprisingly well written story.  It's also pretty lenghty for an indie game.

I would very much recommend Shadow Warrior to anyone who loves some good old fps and hack 'n' slash action.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A shining example of a First Person Shooter done right.
No wee-wee-spunk-gargle here.

All the weapons feel diferent, and no one of them seems ultimately better than another. They all have a good impact as well. And the sword? I pretty much used the sword 99% of the time my first playthrough. It's fantastic. Slice through enemy demons spraying their blood and body parts everywhere. I hear demon blood is good for your skin, so don't feel bad being covered in it.

Great game. If you're not willing to pay full price, get it on sale. Not only is the action good but it's funny, and upholds the inappropriateness of the original. The level designs are good as well.
I enjoyed it from start to finish.

reviewText: Going into this game I wasn't expecting much.\nIt's safe to say that all of my expectations were blown away. It's way more fun than it has any right to be. Sure the upgrade elements are shoe horned in, sure one of the 3 upgrade trees is completely worthless, sure the melee combat does whatever the ♥♥♥♥ it wants, sure it has memes and cheesy dialogue, but it's still amazingly fun. It's not particularly hard, but it should pose a moderate challenge on the higher difficulties.

reviewText:
A incredible fun game, with a lot of focus on Sword fighting and just gernerally murdering stuff.
You get a Katana as your first weapon, and i personally found it to be the most fun to use. You get a lot of the normal old-school FPS weapons (SMG, Pistol, Rocket launcher, Crossbow etc.) But they all felt very stiff. But they're not the interesting part of this gime.

You have 3 things you can upgrade, your skills, powers, and weapons. Skils are for stuf like more health, faster run speed, new katana abilities, Something that a normal person would be able to develop generally. Then there is the powers. 4 different in total. They are all executed by doing a movement key twice then right-click (Movement key twice + left click is for the katana skills). This might seem difficult at first, but it actually works really well, and gives you easy access to all your abilities. My favorite personally, was the flux. By Pressing S twice, and then right-click, you would charge up your first. When you released right-click, it would throw a long line into the ground, that would lift enemies up in the air for several seconds. Its amazing using the flux, then blowing someones head off with a shotgun.

The enemies are a bit weird though.

They're mostly Demons.

Not a concept i enjoyed too much, but you find a few human enemies in some sections too. The demons all have specific abilities, and there are major and minor.

The minor are the ones you might be able to slash to pieces in one or few hits, while the major can take a while to kill.
Of the minor demons, we have your usual run and hit you zombie. The radioactive that explode when you get near or shoot them. The shielders and the invisibles.

The shielders has to be the enemy i dreaded the most, not only do they block your attacks, they keep looking in your direction and you have to either throw them down, or hit the shield until it breaks. It can take a while and really breaks the flow of the game, when you're spinning around and killing litearlly everybody around you, except for them.

Of the major enemies, there are 3: The Warlord, The Charger, and the Shaman. The major are a bit more interesting, so i'll talk about them.

The shaman will summon and resurrect nearby enemies, and just keep doing this until you kill him. After hes around halfway dead, he will create a green unbreakable barrier, and summon some skeletons that flash with green colors. After you kill the skeletons, the shield breaks and you can finish him off.

The Warlord will enrage nearby eneies (Which is, make them darker, and make them more powerful. Enemies can also be enraged if you use abilities or powers near them, even if there isin't a warlord there) He will also try to smash you, a lot. So every few seconds, he will throw a really fast red line, and if you touch it, he will pull you to him, and he will smash the ground.

The final one is the charger. Hes simple, and kind of boring to be honest. He will charge you, you evade it near a wall. He hits the wall. You slice his back a few times. Rinse and repeat. It just takes so long to kill these guys, that the fun quickly dies from fighting them.

But of all enemies, the most interesting one is the bosses. There are a total of 3 Demon bosses, and they're all amazing to fight. They're HUGE, and the shadow realm is just right-out eyecandy. They are all very Zelda-ish, and its very fun.

All in all, if you have ever played Red steel 1 or 2, and enjoyed it. Or just want to enjoy a throwback to the old FPS with a mix of very interesting sword fighting, you should pick this game up.

9/10

reviewText:
A extremely fun game with beautiful graphics, atmosphere and detailed world. One of the best games I have played in a long time.

The combat is so much fun, slashing and destroying with your katana and powers, you have the ability to destroy almost everything around you. I prefer mostly using the katana, I find it much more fun than using guns which almost feel pointless as they don't seem as strong, effective or fun as the katana.

It has quite a good story line with amusing dialogue from Wang, upgradable weapons, powers and skills and hidden things to find for those who take the time to explore thoroughly.

The only thing I didn't like is that you have to double tap a direction then hold and release lmb or rmb to use a katana ability or power which makes it feel a bit slow to execute.

This game is a definite must play  I give it a rating of 8/10.

reviewText:
I have enjoyed this game WAY more than any other single player FPS I have played. The sheer amount of power you feel while playing as Lo Wang is just great.

There's a lot of nuance to its experience that most reviewers fail to mention. Now maybe it's better if you are surprised by them once you play the game;
however...IF you're on the fence and want to know what makes this game STAND OUT..., THEN keep reading.
**ONE story-related SPOILER AHEAD, but it is something you find out in the first chapter**
(it's the 3rd '+')
******************
***************
************
*********
******
****
**
*
+GREAT for relieving stress
+can chop off enemy's leg just to watch him hop around and grab his leg in pain
(each enemy is sliced n' diced exactly how it should be, with directional slices)
+have this 'spirit' ally with you & it talks to you throughout the game (with comedic results)
+/- it's an arena shooter, meaning you will kill a group of enemies, then explore/relax until you run into the next batch
+can heal yourself with a magical skill (heals up to 60% of your max hp, but can be upgraded to more)
- a few of the chapters are too long IMO (3 or 4 chapters took ≈2 hrs to complete)
- no co-op or multi-player
+are secret items to collect in every level
+well balanced enemies/combat
+can simultaneously do magic in one hand and use weapon in the other. oh yeah!

20-23 hours to complete (story mode)
for most people, but took me 25 hrs. in-game time



Edit 1:fixed typos
Edit 2: After beating the game, I edited the line about a few of the chapters [being] too long..."
Edit 3: added approx. time to complete campaign
Edit 4: took out "I love this game!" so you don't think I'm totally biased. & added more explanation of the 'slicing and dicing' mechanics of this game under the pros & cons section"

reviewText:
God, Shadow Warrior is an amazing game. I enjoyed every bit of it and with a great sense of humor, Lo Wang and Hoji became my favorite video game characters.

PROS:

+ Amazing graphics.
+ Decent gameplay.
+ Great level design.
+ A wonderful sense of humor that made me laugh out loud so many times.
+ Long gameplay.

CONS:

- Heroic Mode. What were the developers thinking while they putting this annoying mode in this game? I was able to complete the game on Heroic but it was a pain in the ♥♥♥.
- Bugs. I dashed into stairs and I died.
- Poorly optimized. I was able to run it on ultra with 60 FPS but people with poor system says they can't even run it on lowest settings even if they had the minimum system requirements.

reviewText:
Positive
+ The sword gameplay is simply a blast; the gore effects especially make sure that chopping up enemies is always satisfying
+ The upgrade system enhances both sword and gun gameplay, as well as giving a large variety of ways to give slight improvements to your character
+ Graphics are very well detailed, including both gorgeous backgrounds and high quality textures, without a single drop in frame rate
+ Manages to effectively capture the charm of the original game and Lo Wang himself (minus the racism), including many comedic references to the original game and pop-culture in general
+ Lengthy campaign for a modern first-person shooter (approximately 10 hours on Normal difficulty), with interesting characters and a neat little story making sure to keep you entertained until the end.


Negative
- The guns seem lacking in firepower for the most part (especially the submachine gun); the sword gameplay completely overshadows it.


Verdict
“Easily the best FPS from 2013, and one of my all-time favourites. The extensive swordplay alone makes the game fun and memorable enough, as well as the character Lo Wang reinstating his place in the modern era of gaming. If you’re a fan of first-person shooters or games in general, I’d highly recommend it.”

8.5/10 TJBs

reviewText:
This Re-interpretation of the classic 1997 shooter actually pleasantly suprised me in several ways in just how good it is.
The combat system for a start is immensely satisfying, The sword combat is implemented so well that along with chivalry it's the most fun i've had doing first person melee combat.
Guns are also really fun to use thanks to the dismemberment of all enemy limbs in the game as well as some of the more unique weapons from the original game such as the enemy heart and head.

The graphics are relatively eye pleasing featuring a lot of colour, rich texture quality and a nice variety of environments to explore in, although monotony does set in at times through either the same type of environment repeating themselves too many times (Enough of the damn Bamboo Forests) or a level going on for too long.

The plot was also somewhat suprising in how intriguing it was and the characters are funny/interesting enough to not be annoying, it's also a decent sized game at around a dozen hours and you can get plenty of replay value maxing out all of the characters abilites and unlocking all of his skills.

So in summary as long as you don't expect a true remake of the original shooter you should have a blast playing this and for me this was one of the best shooters of 2013.

reviewText:
“You’ve got Wang!”

That’s right folks, Lo Wang returns in Shadow Warrior, a reimagining of 3D Realms’ classic FPS. Flying Wild Hogs has re-created another old-school shooter in a generation where many AAA shooters have evolved to eschew health packs for health regeneration while focusing on big, grandiose set pieces. Shadow Warrior bucks the current trend by having health packs, linear gameplay, and smaller scripted events.

As Wang, a corporate agent for Zilla Enterprises, I was sent to broker a deal for the Nobitsura Kage – an ancient sword. However the deal went south and I suddenly found myself enfolded into a story filled with dark and mystical forces while trying to recover the sword. No longer was I fighting just human thugs, but demonic minions too; all with a spirit sidekick. And while the story might start out simply enough, by the end the scope broadens.

But don’t let me fool you into thinking that this is a completely somber story. True to the classic game the re-make contains a lot of humor that kept me smiling and laughing as I played. From the dialogue, quips from Wang, and even the fortune cookies I picked up, I had a lot of fun from beginning to end. I’d have to agree with a particular cookie that read, “A Wang in the hand is worth two in the bush.”

To read the rest of my review visit Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-shadow-warrior/

Definitely one of the biggest surprises of the year for me possibly even the decade, the game is just amazing fun from beginning to end with its addictive gory action and witty humor, so if you like that kind of stuff you need to own this game,

To put it in terms that could truly define what this game is, this game is what Duke Nukem Forever should have been pure and simple.

Here's hoping for a sequel.

reviewText: The combat feels very fluid and controls are amazing. It feels right when you hit an enemy with your sword, and switching between guns doesnt take you out of the moment. Combos are easy to perform, but doesnt mean you will perform them by accident. In big fights you feel like a true badass when you switch back and forth between weapons and perform special moves  and obliterate everything. The story is rather forgetful and I forgot what was going on halfway through which was a shame. There is a part in the game where a lot of conversation is empty (you will know what I mean when it happens) which ruins a good part of the game. The humor between the 2 characters is quite entertaining and it goes downhill a bit when this is missing for a good while\n\n9/10

reviewText: After a great Hard reset of flying wild hog came time for Shadow Warrior. Original released in 1997. I have not played the original so I will not be compared. But I will try to say something about the new version. You can see similar arrangement as in HR. Sprint, fight,bosses and different functions weapons. However, in my opinion, HR is a better game from Flying Wild Hog. But let's get to the meat. The graphics are good but uneven. Picturesque locations delight the eye and not once can admire the work of graphic designers. But up close the graphics are not so great. No less is fine. I don't play on highest graphics settings. Gameplay is good and fight with katana is very good. To bring a special need such a blow, press 2x W and LMB. When it is mastered can make fun. However, a larger number of different enemies will be easier to use other weapons. At least to me it was easier. Weapons are many but some are not very effective and the feeling of shooting in some of the less impressive. Unfortunately, sometimes the game is frustrating. For me it was for this that some of the levels and enemies were poorly designed.  Level of exploding enemies is terribly weak. A fight with the boss very easy and unsatisfying. The music is atmospheric and the sounds of enemies and weapons are at a good level. The game is not really in my style (kung fu) but I have fun. The story and the main character are fine although his statements are not as funny as Serious Sam or Duke Nukem. Sometimes they are childish and not funny. The game has a lot of easter eggs and funny moments like Fortune cookies. Some jokes can be understood only did the Poles because the Polish game studio. But it should not be a big problem for other players. The game also has a survival mode but only single so it's a big minus, and does not have a multiplayer mode. In summary. The game is good and I recommend you buy it at some sales. Graphics 8/10 Audio 8+/10 Gameplay 8+/10 Final verdict 7+/10.

reviewText:
Decent, fun FPS with swordplay and an engaging and satisfying variety of ways to dismember and kill demons. The jokes also made me smile at times.

My PC isn't the fastest, with only a Radeon HD6970, but I was able to run it well enough at 2560x1600 at medium visual quality settings.

If you're moderately good at FPSes you might want to try the Insane difficulty level; I played on Hard and died only occasionally, with the more intense battles only taking another go or two/three to get past, so it felt like Medium to me. (I'm only of average'ish ability and haven't played FPSes for a while.)

reviewText:
This has to be the most overlooked fps ever. This game brings back the classic fps feeling, it's like Duke Nukem meets Ninja Gaiden. It has a dark and serious story but a humorous protagonist who doesn't take too much seriously.

I spend most of the time using the katana because of how good cutting feel. Guns aren't very powerful before you upgrade them, but it adds more fun to the game, you feel like you're progressing all the time like a true martial art student. You also unlock many abilities, one for katana moves and one for ki powers.

This game is full of secret areas like good old Doom-likes and many of those are areas from the original Shadow Warrior bringing pure nostalgia. They are also very rewarding, giving you karma and money. I have so much fun looking for secrets and references that I often forget the main path.

At the end of a level there is a screen showing you how many secrets you found, how many enemies you killed and how much karma you gained and could have gained. This is something that was in a lot of Doom-likes that would bring a lot of replayability. There is also a survival mode that can be fun once you finish the game, and the ability to replay the game with all your weapons and powers.

If you're tired of rushed and overhyped modern fps aimed toward casuals and want to feel like you're playing a classic fps again, this game is for you.

reviewText: Shadow Warrior is a in many aspects successful reimagining of the 3D Realms classic from 1997. In this review I will describe how it holds up in comparison and try to cut right to the chase.\n\nThe level design isn't quite as open and doesn't offer as many secrets as the original, but you can tell that Flying Wild Hog put a lot of love and work into this project. The combat is extremely fun and satisfying, especially the different katana moves. The weapons are varied, fun to use and none of them feel unneccessary or even useless. The story is fairly cheesy, so I guess you could say they nailed this aspect. Shadow Warrior and a serious story don't mix as far as I'm concerned. The voice acting is great, even though I miss Lo Wang's original voice. The quips are hit and miss, but overall quite funny. What really impresses me about this game is that it feels like an almost perfect blend of retro" and modern game design. Many developers have aspired to do that and most of them failed. Flying Wild Hog managed to pull it off
date:
which deserves much respect.

I've spent about 21 hours on Shadow Warrior and enjoyed it a lot. I'm planning to replay it at some point.

Bottom line: If you aren't offended by strong video game violence and dark
hoursPlayed: you will have a great time with this game!"

reviewText:
Before I bought this game, I read some reviews and watched some videos. The game looked absolutely fantastic! And, at first, it was. At first, the level design was good, the enemies got harder over time, and there were variations of them. But after awhile...the level design goes downhill. Also, they don't put many different enemies in the game after chapter...7 I want to say. Also I'd like to add that the bosses are extremely simple. First, you shoot off their armor pieces, they go down, you destroy their crystals, etc, etc. This is for every. Single. Boss.

It just seems like the game is completely awesome for a good 2 hours, then Flying Hog just kind of...ran out of ideas? I'm not sure what happened. Another thing is that the game is about 10 hours long (I played on normal difficulty), and really doesn't have any replay value. There's no extras. Finally, the skills and the powers and things. Lots of them are just plain useless, and you won't ever use them. Maybe it was because I was playing on normal mode, but still, I felt like if I didn't spend most of the power-up points I got, then I'd be okay and could keep playing the game.

Now on to the good things. The sword mechanics are actually very good! You can even set it to an advanced mode in options to make the sword swing to where you move your mouse. Slicing up enemies is VERY satisfying. Also dual uzis is pretty much epic in my book. Firing 3 rockets at once while using a laser to determine where they'll hit? Play Shadow Warrior. Like to use a flamethrower WITH a GRENADE LAUNCHER attached?? Play Shadow Warrior. Like to behead six demons at once with a katana??!? Play Shadow Warrior.

Despite some of the bad things, this game is fun. It's a good game. Not great, but good. I'll definitely recommend this game, but try to get it on sale.

reviewText:
There's been quite a number of reboots to classic FPS franchises in recent years. However most of them have turned out to be ultimately dissapointing, with Duke Nukem Forever being overall a shoddy experience and Rise of the Triad bringing a full old school experience but also including numerous design faults. So next up on the list is Shadow Warrior.

You play as Lo Wang, who aside from being a walking ♥♥♥♥ joke has been sent to retreve a sword from an organisation by any means necessary. This inevitably doesn't go smoothly and thus there are demons all across the land, the rest of the game from then on is a quest for this mystical sword called the Nobitsura Kage. The plot itself is fairly standard affair for a game of this sort, never really reaching beyond decent. There are also some issues regarding the stories tone although it’s not too huge an issue. Although story qualms are a minor issue it doesn't detract from the game when looking at the main reason that one would play it, the gameplay.

Gameplay is the make or break aspect of these throwback FPS's. Thankfully what we're given is a vicious thrill ride that entertains all throughout its playtime. One of the more interesting aspects to the original Shadow Warrior was that you could use a sword as a melee weapon, the reboot takes this side weapon and makes it the forefront of the game which turns out to be the best decision they could have made. The sword play in Shadow Warrior is simply one of the best melee systems that's been put into any game. You'll be in giggly fits of glee slicing through the demon horde in Shadow Warrior as each slice carves through enemies like butter. Limbs flying everywhere, heads lopped off and all done with an over the top gorey attitude. What makes the sword even better is that it's always a valid option, even until the final fights. However there are also an array of traditional guns like a revolver, machine gun and rocket launcher. Whilst these weapons aren't as fun to use as the sword, they add some nice variety to the game and are prove to be necessary with certain enemies. Also added in the mix are special Ki abilites that allow you to pull of magical powers such as pushing enemies away or healing, add in a dodge mechanic and Shadow Warrior provides a fairly robust and entertaining set of tools to be used at your disposal on your demonic foes.

However this could all be a repeat instance of Rise of the Triad, which had great gameplay but suffered due to poor design. Thankfully Shadow Warrior avoids most of these pitfalls but doesn't necessarily come out unscathed. For one, levels are usually fairly linear rather than a mass sprawling map to explore, also the game utilises a checkpoint system but you are able to use normal saves and quick saves anywhere you like. There are however a few issues. As with most throwback titles like this there can be issues with backtracking in that it can become easy to get lost looking for the one door to progress to the next part of the level. Also I did encounter an issue during a fight where an enemy was stuck somewhere in the level which made progression impossible, this was fixed by reloading an old save. Aside from that however the game holds up design-wise.

Graphically the game actually looks really nice for the most part. Thanks to the eastern setting there is an abundance of colour and vibrancy that makes the environments pop, leaving you truely impressed with some of the images. The game does find iself being bogged down near the middle with seemingly endless ship environments but they don't last too long in retrospect and end just as it would get truely tedious. There are also some texture pop-in issues but they were few and far between.

Shadow Warrior is back with a bang! With its emphasis on sadisticly satisfying sword play Shadow Warrior manages to carve itself a unique indentity within the FPS genre. Those who truely appreciate and love old school FPS or melee combat in games should pick up that katana and have a bloodsoaked bash with Wang.

reviewText:
An absolute hidden gem of a game that surprised me with each and every aspect of it's design.

I was not expecting this much depth out of the story or mechanics; specifically in the upgrade/skill system. While the game does have certain old school FPS sensibilities (collecting ammo/health, finding secrets, unlocking doors to progress) it does not neglect the narrative and totally sucked me into the story with decent writing and top-notch voice acting and all that made me want to continue playing the game for more than just the gameplay.

The gameplay (which even on it's own) is amazing and the visceral feeling of gunning down, blowing up and, most importantly, slicing up enemies is truly a delight. Especially especially using the katana which (in my humble opinion) is the best melee weapon I've ever used in a game so far.

The fact that the developers have taken the time and effort to include many many gore-y animations for when you go on a rampage shows they know what makes for a satisfying experience. As for the other weapons: all of them are wonderfully designed with alternate firemodes each and are generally a joy to use in their own ways; after all these are some of the Painkiller devs we're talking about.

Finally, the cherry on top for me would be the sense of humor and the (non-pandering) pop-culture references which really make you feel at home with everything from Star Wars to Taxi Driver. Everything just has a fun-loving and playful feel to it.

So, yeah, I haven't covered everything, but seriously watch the trailers and download the demo (yeah.. remember those?) and then seriously consider purchasing this little slice of gold.

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is a quite enjoyable shooter which doesn't take itself seriously.
The dialogues between your protagonist and the demon are also just too hilarious.

The focus lies on melee combat with your katana, therefore most of your ranged weapons are weak.
You can upgrade your weapons with money found in the levels, but most of them stay weak - an odd design decision, since it's a shooter.
After every fight you will get a rating which decides how many karma points you earn. You can spend them on attributes or skills like more health and special attacks with your katana.

Besides some monotony problems in the last chapters and the more or less weak firearms I really enjoyed the humour,  the challenging fights, slashing through demon hordes and playing something different than the typical aim-down-the-sights-hp-reg-cover-shooters.

reviewText:
Defeated sword-wielding men in black suit. Killed a thousand demons. Beheaded an archdemon and used his head to kill more demons.

Almost got whacked by a white rabbit.

10/10 - Would Like More Wang

--

Seriously: This is a very good, story-driven shooter in the vein of ye olden days. It starts off (and keeps being) very wacky, with a not-so-subtle 80s-to-90s action movie vibe (quiffs and one-liners galore), but - without going into spoilerish details - turns into something almost dramatic, and sad in the end.

The gameplay is fast and furious, but not unfair. Ok, sometimes you might get squiched in a cavalcade of demons, but even if push comes to shove, the auto-save system kicks in and you don't lose much progress. Of note are the chapters, or levels: It's not the tunnelvision you might be used from current shooters, but rather something with actual thought in the design. There are no quest markers, no You are going the wrong way". Sometimes you have to backtrack
hoursPlayed: or not so hidden

reviewText: This fps has very enjoyable game play with lots of interesting guns. Additionally there is one of the best katana combat systems in this game. The story is not particularly amazing or deep but I personalyy didnt care because the gameplay was so fun. The campaign has a decent length to it and the arena mode more than covers any desired replay value. Then enemie variety is great with everything from cannon fodder to massive bosses. Although there was one enemy type that was just a pain to deal with. It was a charger character with one vulnerable weak spot. It kept messing with the flow of the game since it would regularly be the last foe standing and take a minute or two to bring down one of them. This could take me as long as six minutes when there were four to kill. However the rest presented and ideal challenge and with lots of ways to deal with them. Ammo is pretty plentiful so if you are looking to be forced to change weapons that will not be quite the case. You will not be able to use the same weapon for the whole game since ammo drops are not that plentiful but a skilled player could mangage to use only two weapons. The exception to this previous statment is the  katana, which can be used for the whole game for obvious reasons. I can not comment on the viscera clean up detail bonus game since I have not played it.

reviewText: Shadow Warrior 2013 is a reboot of the 1997 classic by 3-D Realms developed by Flying Wild Hog and published by Devolver Digital. The game has you take the role of Lo Wang, a sarcastic and awesome protagonist who is told by the head of Zilla Industries to retrieve an ancient sword that goes by the name Nobitsura Kage" which is a weapon that is said to have connections with ancient Gods and possess power unlike anything mankind has ever seen. Along the way Lo Wang will meet a spirit known as "Hoji"
date: who helps Wang on his quest to retrieve the Nobitsura Kage.\n\nThe gameplay is a mix between an old school first person shooter and a Hack-and-slash

reviewText: Shadow Warrior is one of the best FPS's I've played this year, and possibly more rewarding than Bioshock Infinite in many aspects, though the story is a bit silly. That being said, the hand-drawn cutscenes and resolution of the story is engaging and emotional, despite all of the ♥♥♥♥ jokes made about the protagonist's name: Lo Wang. He goes from being an arrogant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to a respectable hero, and it makes for a pretty decent story. It's longer than Hard Reset and of the same caliber: outstanding and underrated, especially considering what it is. As mentioned before, the length is somewhat intimidating when one considers replaying Shadow Warrior. I'm sure I'll replay it someday soon.

reviewText: At first I was suspicious of this game, since I've never heard from its predecessor before but the game managed to almost instantly correct my opinion on it. This is a wonderful remake. The graphics are beautiful and to the point, the combat is fluid, engaging and entertaining, the story is okay (I don't expect much anymore, thank you, game industry[/sarcasm off]) and the upgrading is one of the better systems. Useful skills and spells you actually use instead of having them for funsies. Although I tend to use mainly the katana but that is personal preference, I guess. There's a lot of weapons.\n\ntl;dr This game is an amazing amalgamation of Dark Messiah, Serious Sam and Painkiller. Get it!

reviewText:
What can i say? after 7 hours of recorded gameplay i can tell that this is a good game (i'm sure i'm nowhere near the end yet at this point). Knowing this was going to be developed by a company like Flying Wild Hog, i had high hopes. Didn't pick it up at release, but boy does it deserve the full price tag. Shadow Warrior is probably the most enjoyable single player FPS i've played in a long time (Bulletstorm coming close enough). I was a huge fan of the original Shadow Warrior from 1997, so playing this one felt like home sweet home.

It has the classic humour and the swordsplay is a pleasent surprise and loads of fun (compared to the basic swordsplay back in the day). All the upgrades seem interesting too and add a lot to the game to keep it interesting. Combat with the weapons is fun, but i always find myself going back to the katana easily. The Soundtrack gives the game a great athmosphere and keeps giving great amount of goosebumps during the battles, making them seem epic every time you get in trouble with the demons, great work in that aspect as well.

All in all, i recommend this to anybody who likes/liked Bulletstorm, Serious Sam series and the like, or even for old timers who grew up with the original SW, Quake, Blood, Duke Nukem and so forth. Pure mindless FPS fun that keeps you smiling and laughing all around. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is an FPS reboot of the classic game of the same name. You play as Lo Wang, a sword and gun wielding one-liner machine on a mission to save the world from demons.

What sets apart Shadow Warrior from the multitude of other FPS games is the swordplay. While the gunplay is not the most exciting you will see in the genre, with the guns not feeling powerful enough, the swords are really second to none. There are many special moves, each with their own uses, and there is a great sense of satisfaction to be felt as you see limbs and heads fly off your enemies. The best approach is probably to mix up the two weapons, but the more fun approach may be swords only.

The graphics are ok if not spectacular for their time. There was recently a new graphics overhaul released for free, but I did not notice much of a difference. Maybe this is due to the graphics being a little forgettable in the first place.

The story and writing is ridiculous and par for the course for 90's FPS games. Save the world while killing hordes and hordes of bullet sponge enemies. How Lo Wang finds time to think of his witty remarks during his genocidal spree, I may never know.

The issue I found with Shadow Warrior is that it all starts feeling a little samey after a few levels. I kind of lost my will to continue shooting and chopping up demons after about 4 hours. I wouldn't say that makes the game a failure, just that I got my fill before it was over. The story is definitely secondary to the gameplay, which I enjoyed, but I really had no wish to see the game the whole way through. Overall I felt like I got my money's worth out of the game, but I got it on sale. Would I be happy if I paid $40, probably not. I couldn't recommend it at that price. But is it worth a play if you find it on sale? Absolutely.

Grade: B

reviewText:
Incredible game. One of my favorite FPS games of all time easily. Especially after the 1.5 patch.

Pros:
* Heavily optimized (runs 200+ fps most of the time maxed out)
* Graphics
* Satisfying combat (like bullet storm but more interesting)
* Great enemy design
* Great sound
* Really good story (surprising, but it gets really cool towards the end)
* Some replay value simply because its so fun

Cons:
* Could use a few more enemy types
* Couple bosses have obnoxious mechanics
* Beware of stairs

9/10 (+1/-1)

reviewText:
Surprising can be used to summarize just about everything about this game. Surprisingly fun gameplay, surprisingly interesting mechanics and leveling, surprisingly funny dialog, surprisingly fun collectables/unlockables, surprisingly lengthy, surprisingly engaging story, surprisingly interesting environments, surprisingly fun.

I went in expecting a short, fun, low-investment arcade shooter, but it definitely wasn't short, and I was definitely invested.

Surpassed my expectations in every way.

reviewText:
The reboot lacks polish, the combat is unbalanced (the Katana is overpowered as hell and there isn't much point in using many of the other weapons), and some of the levels have awful structure to them. But the visceral melee combat with its chaotic gore is so awesome, that it is powerful enough to overshadow most of the titles flaws. Shadow Warrior is not a perfect re-imagining of the 90s shooter, but it's pretty damn close.

reviewText:
Wow, Shadow Warrior, what a game. I haven't played anything like this in a while, something that I can just sink into and have tons of fun in. This game's combat is really different than most modern day FPSs(though most of the time it's hard to call this game a shooter). The game's combat is much more like old shooters, where instead of hiding behind walls , you're running around as fast as you can blowing enemies to bits. Although there's one key difference, you're not blowing them to bits....you're slicing them to bits! And that's where this game gets interesting, your primary weapon is a samurai sword that you'll have fun running around and swinging through demons for hours. The gameplay of Shadow Warrior is great, fast paced, fun sword action, and some ancient ninja magic to spice things up. However, for some reason you can also use guns. The guns seem really out of place, the shooting isn't that great, but thankfully you don't have to use them all that often excpet for....bosses. Bosses are one of the biggest complaint of the gameplay.  For some reason in this awsome game about using a sweet sword you have to switch to guns for these guys. The bosses are tedious, unfun, and really slow down the pacing. There aren't a lot of bosses though, and there is plenty of fun sword action between them.

This game looks fantastic. It is mostly set in Japan, and they really use that to their advantage. Almost everything is styled  in kind of a traditional Japanese designwith cherry blossoms and shrines, it all looks great.

Overall this game is a definative 'play it!' The combat is super fun and I kept telling myself 'just one more level' every time I needed to go. You'll have tons of fun hacking up demons in a beautiful Japanese environment.

reviewText:
Well with no doubt this was one of the biggest 2013 surprise, a FPS with lot of action, very different from what we are accustom. This one was a retro-reboot inspired on the Shadow Warrior released in 1997.

Here we control Lo Wang, a ninja mercenary from modern day time with excellent humor sense, we fight against demons hordes. Game is quite big, there are 17 large chapters, but linear levels with a good amount of secrets and easter eggs to discover.

Besides the good humor sense that game gives us, the combat system very smooth and is very varied, you have nice combos to make, with your sword or weapons.  You get a good number of weapons added to your arsenal as you progress through the game and can carry all of them with you. The combat also has a fantastic melee element with the katana that you start the game with.

We also have a progression and upgrade system, were we can upgrade our skills and get new powers with the KI crystals. When you upgrade the powers or the skills you can move faster, regenerate health easily or get a new power to Wang use.

Now the worst part of this game was definitely the gameplay, is very boring at least for me, we kill, we follow the goal that most of times is destroy a statue that is blocking a magical door and nothing else to do. Yeah we can find the easter eggs and some other secrets but still, i did expect more on this.

Overall I was surprised at how good this game was. If you are a fan of old-school, fast paced FPS action with a sense of humor then I highly recommend this game.

~ 7/10
