reviewText:
What to say first about this amazing game? This is some of the most fun I've ever had playing an FPS game - that's what Shadow Warrior is from start to finish: pure fun.

You play as Lo Wang, an assassin sent on a seemingly menial task, until things get completely out of hand with a full blown demonic invasion. Lo Wang and the witty and insightful deuteragonist Hoji, are a delight to listen and their personalities complement each other's perfectly, constantly exchanging light hearted, hilarious quips and wisecracks, but also being serious when circumstances demand. They are a match made in heaven - or hell, in this case. You can't help but chuckle when you listen to them. The story is inspired by old Asian legends and is surprisingly good. It doesn't make much sense at first but things get tied together rather nicely towards the end.

The combat (which you'll be doing a LOT of) is extremely satisfying and gory. The hectic, always-mobile nature of the fights will keep you to the edge of your seat, especially in the endgame chaotic battles. The gradual introduction of new enemies and weapons keep things interesting. Use variety in your kills and you'll be rewarded extra Karma points, which give you access to a detailed skill tree that you can customize according to your playstyle. This encouragement to use variety lends an almost cinematic quality to some fights, reminiscent of Hong Kong cinema. There are plenty of cool weapons to select from, which can be upgraded with modifications you can buy throughout the game with such over the top options as to add a grenade launcher to your flamethrower, among others.

The levels are beautifully designed, with varying locales each gorgeous in its own right. The scenery is so nice that you can't help but think at times that you're looking at a postcard - albeit one with pools of blood and dead bodies littered about. It is not always obvious where to go and you might get lost at times, but try to get to the glowing" door and you'll be alright. Secrets are creatively hidden
date: and there are references to the old Shadow Warrior and other titles scattered all over the place.\n\nLast but not least - I did not encounter a single bug during my playthrough
recommended: a tell tale sign of a very well polished game.\n\nThere are flaws however
hoursPlayed: although these are more of minor gripes than actual glaring flaws. The one that vexed me the most was that the most dangerous enemies in the entire game are the stairs. That's right: if you dash when at the top of most stairs in the game
voteText: you will plunge to your death. Lo Wang can survive being shot and slashed
helpfulPercent: but a 2 meter drop will either kill him instantly or leave his life hanging by a thread. Another thing was that the rating system at the end of each battle is unpredictable at times
votesHelpful: giving you 2/5 stars even if you are quick
votesTotal: accurate
votesFunny: and use variety
commentsCount: and at other times rewarding you with 5/5 stars for no discernable reason (as far as I can tell). The loading times between levels often take quite a while as well.\n\nAll in all however
column16: fantastic game. I really hope Flying Wild Hog makes a sequel to this."

reviewText:
You may wonder if this game is good and the answer is YES. Remember playing DNF and wishing they would just copy the game formula and make a great game instead of making yet another abysmal monster with QTE, regen, weapon limit and idiotic vehicle levels.
Well, this game did remake job RIGHT.
If you loved those golden age of FPS games powered by the BUILD engine (ROTT, Redneck Rampage, DN3D, Powerslave, etc etc), you will really really enjoy the SW.

A few things I love the most:
* Almost everything can be destroyed / exploded.
* Three different upgrade systems (weapon upgrades, skill tree, separate ability tree with separate resource pool)
* ♥♥♥♥ING KATANA
* Classic free-to-explore level layouts with tons of secret places. (I wish I had that BUILD-style map overlay)
* Classic weapon set (Pistol, SMG, shotgun, boomsticks, etc) - no modern two weapon slots ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.
* Healthkits, no regen. (Well, technically there is regen, but it is tied to the skill system)

tl;dr - classical FPS with a remastered graphic that will make you cry in joy.

reviewText:
Playing at Atomic speed, fully adreanlized and highly caffenated Shadow Warrior never slows down. A mix of old school and modern tech ingrediants Flying Wild Hog knows guns and action and prove it again with their second FPS game.

In Shadow Warrior you play as Lo Wang who while on a mission to retrieve a sacred sword to destroy demons from another dimension(totally cliche) you totally get blindsided into the real story of a family tradgedy. Its actually pretty good and the ending is very bittersweet. But if you didnt come to the game for story thats ok, cutscense can be skipped at the tap of a button and the story is told in less than 5 minutes i would guess but totally worth paying attention.

The gameplay is very simple, enter an area kill everything. There is no cover and no mercy. Even after mini boss fights enemies will continue to keep coming. There is a semi generous save system in place and you can heal yourself at anytime but trust me there will be times when you question both.

You will be given your basic FPS arsenal from guns, crossbow, flamthowers and rocket launchers that are all upgradeable as well as some mystical powers and perks to choose. All the weopns and powers are useful and i never found myself sticking to one or another. Constantly cycling through weapons and powers during each battle is recommeded as each encounter is graded. The more variety the more experience you earn towards a perk upgrade.

Shawdow Warrior is a good looking game(2013) though most of it comes from the enviorments, and weapons. Most enemies are not that memorable and human charcters are minimal in the game and are very basic looking. A game can be strengthened by graphics and while this doesnt raise the bar it will never diminsh the actual game with age.

One of the weakest parts of the game is enemy variety. This is a long game 20+ hrs and i can name every enemy i hate i one hand. More variety would be welcome but the horde packages, enviroments and your constant upgrades helped differentiate each encounter.

I also have to mention the huomor that is constantly up front and had me laughin out loud. Also, each level there is numerous secrets to be found which in itself is a game.

Overall Shadow Warrior is an awesome game, maybe a bit long, a little weak with enemy variety and the last encouter and boss can be marathons but well worth getting your Wang on. A must buy for fans of horde levels, Doom, Wolfenstein, FPS type games.

Positives
Total Bang for your Buck
Great setting, enviorments, music
Good story
Weapons, powers, skill tress
Non Stop Action
Humor, voice acting

Negatives
Enemy variety
Sometimes hard to figure which way to go
One trick pony
Marathon Boss at the end
A little long

reviewText: Slice a demon in half with a katana. Behead a demon with a crossbow bolt. Shoot a demon with a sticky bomb, then detonate him near an explosive barrel and start a room-clearing chain reaction. Cut a demon in half and get bonus points for dismembering his dead body. If any of these activites appeals to your inner psycho, then Shadow Warrior is the game for you. This game is an intensely gory and ultraviolent rampage through some great environments: cities, graveyards, tranquil shrines, even the Shadow Realm itself. Shadow Warrior sets a high bar for remakes of classic games. The graphics are stunning and the combat is excellent, if unequaled. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a new shooter. Even better is the continued support of this game by the dev team, who released a massive update 2 years after the game was published, fixing tons of bugs, adding x64 DX11 support, porting the game to Mac and Linux, and making the campaign even more exciting! This is an inredible game and, if you buy it, you will be supporting a great dev team. So grab it on sale or even for full price and let the rampage begin. Wow! That was nice!

reviewText: One of my favourite first-person shooters, Shadow Warrior is a reboot/remake of the classic Build Engine game, Shadow Warrior. While the original is perhaps best known for distastefully racist humour and annoying sword combat, this fresh take by veteran developers Flying Wild Hog (made of People Can Fly ex-pats, of Painkiller fame) is made distinct by large combat areas and refreshingly good sword combat.\n\nIt's an arcade shooter through and through, with audacious weapons, ridiculous enemies, and too many explosions. It combines with really satisfying slice-'em-up mechanics and a sense of weight and urgency not found in lighter retro" shooters like Rise of the Triad

reviewText:
What can i say? after 7 hours of recorded gameplay i can tell that this is a good game (i'm sure i'm nowhere near the end yet at this point). Knowing this was going to be developed by a company like Flying Wild Hog, i had high hopes. Didn't pick it up at release, but boy does it deserve the full price tag. Shadow Warrior is probably the most enjoyable single player FPS i've played in a long time (Bulletstorm coming close enough). I was a huge fan of the original Shadow Warrior from 1997, so playing this one felt like home sweet home.

It has the classic humour and the swordsplay is a pleasent surprise and loads of fun (compared to the basic swordsplay back in the day). All the upgrades seem interesting too and add a lot to the game to keep it interesting. Combat with the weapons is fun, but i always find myself going back to the katana easily. The Soundtrack gives the game a great athmosphere and keeps giving great amount of goosebumps during the battles, making them seem epic every time you get in trouble with the demons, great work in that aspect as well.

All in all, i recommend this to anybody who likes/liked Bulletstorm, Serious Sam series and the like, or even for old timers who grew up with the original SW, Quake, Blood, Duke Nukem and so forth. Pure mindless FPS fun that keeps you smiling and laughing all around. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
There's been quite a number of reboots to classic FPS franchises in recent years. However most of them have turned out to be ultimately dissapointing, with Duke Nukem Forever being overall a shoddy experience and Rise of the Triad bringing a full old school experience but also including numerous design faults. So next up on the list is Shadow Warrior.

You play as Lo Wang, who aside from being a walking ♥♥♥♥ joke has been sent to retreve a sword from an organisation by any means necessary. This inevitably doesn't go smoothly and thus there are demons all across the land, the rest of the game from then on is a quest for this mystical sword called the Nobitsura Kage. The plot itself is fairly standard affair for a game of this sort, never really reaching beyond decent. There are also some issues regarding the stories tone although it’s not too huge an issue. Although story qualms are a minor issue it doesn't detract from the game when looking at the main reason that one would play it, the gameplay.

Gameplay is the make or break aspect of these throwback FPS's. Thankfully what we're given is a vicious thrill ride that entertains all throughout its playtime. One of the more interesting aspects to the original Shadow Warrior was that you could use a sword as a melee weapon, the reboot takes this side weapon and makes it the forefront of the game which turns out to be the best decision they could have made. The sword play in Shadow Warrior is simply one of the best melee systems that's been put into any game. You'll be in giggly fits of glee slicing through the demon horde in Shadow Warrior as each slice carves through enemies like butter. Limbs flying everywhere, heads lopped off and all done with an over the top gorey attitude. What makes the sword even better is that it's always a valid option, even until the final fights. However there are also an array of traditional guns like a revolver, machine gun and rocket launcher. Whilst these weapons aren't as fun to use as the sword, they add some nice variety to the game and are prove to be necessary with certain enemies. Also added in the mix are special Ki abilites that allow you to pull of magical powers such as pushing enemies away or healing, add in a dodge mechanic and Shadow Warrior provides a fairly robust and entertaining set of tools to be used at your disposal on your demonic foes.

However this could all be a repeat instance of Rise of the Triad, which had great gameplay but suffered due to poor design. Thankfully Shadow Warrior avoids most of these pitfalls but doesn't necessarily come out unscathed. For one, levels are usually fairly linear rather than a mass sprawling map to explore, also the game utilises a checkpoint system but you are able to use normal saves and quick saves anywhere you like. There are however a few issues. As with most throwback titles like this there can be issues with backtracking in that it can become easy to get lost looking for the one door to progress to the next part of the level. Also I did encounter an issue during a fight where an enemy was stuck somewhere in the level which made progression impossible, this was fixed by reloading an old save. Aside from that however the game holds up design-wise.

Graphically the game actually looks really nice for the most part. Thanks to the eastern setting there is an abundance of colour and vibrancy that makes the environments pop, leaving you truely impressed with some of the images. The game does find iself being bogged down near the middle with seemingly endless ship environments but they don't last too long in retrospect and end just as it would get truely tedious. There are also some texture pop-in issues but they were few and far between.

Shadow Warrior is back with a bang! With its emphasis on sadisticly satisfying sword play Shadow Warrior manages to carve itself a unique indentity within the FPS genre. Those who truely appreciate and love old school FPS or melee combat in games should pick up that katana and have a bloodsoaked bash with Wang.

reviewText:
The original Shadow Warrior (1997) was a crass and quick cash-in on the popularity of Duke Nukem 3D released a year earlier. What Duke 3D’s Duke was to casual sexism, Shadow Warrior’s Lo Wang was to casual racism. This reboot isn’t as heavy on the corny cliches and stereotyping, but it’s still able to offend the more sensitive types.

Thankfully, beneath the oriental trimmings and plot centered around themes of eastern mysticism, is a first-person shooter that excels at being what it is. Flying Wild Hog knows their stuff, as was proven by their excellent yet overlooked cyberpunk shooter Hard Reset (2011). Unlike the recent Rise of the Triad and Duke Nukem reboots, this one nails it. It’s the run-and-gun hard-boiled action 90s first-person shooter fans crave, but with modern trimmings to keep it fresh.

Using money, karma and ki crystals you find throughout levels, you can upgrade Lo Wang’s guns, buy attachments, and purchase powerful spells. The gunplay works well in conjunction with the spell system, letting you do both at once, for some nice combo moves. After each fight, you get scored based on how creative you were with your bullets, katana and mystical powers. The corny plot even manages to hold it together all the way to the end.

reviewText:
8.5/10
Overview: First Person Melee/Shooter

The Good:

+ Graphics- both on an artistic and technical level everything looks fantastic. Every environment spread across 17 levels feels distinct. The only downside is the developers went heavy with the bloom lighting.

+ Combat is fun and satisfying. The game gives you a variety of different weapons at your disposal. The katana, your main weapon is usually your go to weapon when things start to go bad. It slices and dices enemies to bits. You also have guns that are slowly acquired through the game. The first half of the game seems to be more reliant on your katana and when the larger enemies show up is when your guns start to become more useful. You also have a variety of spells and sword techniques that can give you the upper hand in combat. No matter how you choose to dismember your enemies, you will always have a good time.

+ The game features a very robust upgrade system. Money is used to upgrade your weapons. Each weapon has 3 upgrades. Ki crystals are used to upgrade your spells. Each spell has 4 upgrades. Lastly as you defeat your enemies you gain experience which is used to upgrade your passive abilities and sword techniques.

+ Secrets are scattered throughout every level, some secrets are a throwback to the original game

+ The story starts off very weak however the more it starts to reveal itself the more interesting it gets.  The story is told through comic book style cut scenes that look beautiful. Throughout the game you are accompanied by a demon named Hoji who at first is really annoying but starts to grow on you.

+ The game is very polished. Even with all the explosions and all the effects happening my game barely dropped below 60fps.

+ New Game plus to start the game over with all your upgrades and weapons.

The Average:

You have the ability to dash forward. If you dash on top of a steep staircase you will die. This gets really frustrating as you will be dashing all the time and this will probably be the cause of a lot of needless deaths.  The developers said this bug/Feature" cannot be fixed.

As much fun as the game is
date: it starts to wear itself out in the last few levels. Once you've seen all the enemies and upgraded all that you need
recommended:
fighting the same hordes of enemies over and over again starts getting boring. Luckily the game ends before it really becomes a bigger issue.

This is one of those rare first person shooters where playing with a controller is preferable. The reason being is that you have to input directional inputs to cast your spells and I found it easier to do with a controller than a K/M. In addition the game relies more heavily on melee combat than guns so precise aiming is never really a concern.

Some of the later levels can get a bit confusing.

I felt the last boss was underwhelming. I guess I was expecting something more.


Conclusion

This game is a remake of an old school FPS however this is not an old school fps. Levels are mostly linear with only one way to progress while throwing large amounts of enemies at you for you to dispose. If you enjoy fighting large groups of enemies while you level up your abilities than you will have a good time with the game. Overall this is definitely worth checking out and a very underrated game that deserves a bit more attention.
"

reviewText:
This game starts as a fun and absolutely funny game full of clever Easter eggs that devolves into a grind of repetitive enemies. But there's enough combat fun, just enough of a challenge, and just enough of a story to get you through that grind.

The game isn't optimized the greatest in some parts, specifically the first big boss. Then the lighting is pretty weird as well. But for the most part the game plays smooth and looks pretty. The scenery is diverse level to level and the character animations are *mostly* good.

Starting off the jokes are laugh out loud funny, consistent, and constant. But they evaporate almost entirely about halfway through. Even the fortune cookie jokes littered throughout the game run dry. And any clever Easter eggs are near the beginning. It definitely looses its silly charm as you progress.

The game plays very clean. Each weapon is fun, especially the katana. Couple that with the ability to upgrade the weapons, as well as skill and powers to be unlocked, and the offensive variety stays interesting throughout. I never grew tired of slicing through enemies even after facing the same one for the 1,000th time.

The funny stuff drew me in, the challenge and fluidity of combat kept me going. The game definitely isn't without flaws, but I had fun. There's stretches of repetition and grinding but I felt satisfaction beating each level making the 12+ hours worth it.

Well worth trying it out if it is on sale!

reviewText: Slice a demon in half with a katana. Behead a demon with a crossbow bolt. Shoot a demon with a sticky bomb, then detonate him near an explosive barrel and start a room-clearing chain reaction. Cut a demon in half and get bonus points for dismembering his dead body. If any of these activites appeals to your inner psycho, then Shadow Warrior is the game for you. This game is an intensely gory and ultraviolent rampage through some great environments: cities, graveyards, tranquil shrines, even the Shadow Realm itself. Shadow Warrior sets a high bar for remakes of classic games. The graphics are stunning and the combat is excellent, if unequaled. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a new shooter. Even better is the continued support of this game by the dev team, who released a massive update 2 years after the game was published, fixing tons of bugs, adding x64 DX11 support, porting the game to Mac and Linux, and making the campaign even more exciting! This is an inredible game and, if you buy it, you will be supporting a great dev team. So grab it on sale or even for full price and let the rampage begin. Wow! That was nice!

reviewText: A friend recommended me this game, as I didn't think much of it before. It's your basic run and gun shooter, where you spend most of the time fighting off hordes of enemies. I never played the original so it's nostalgia factor is lost on me. What I will say though is that there is a lot more to this game than I initially thought. The humor is great, the dialogue is quirky/snappy, and the story (while nothing of the mindblowing sort) is suprisingly decent! Some enemies do need a certain strategy to kill. And the campaign is quite lengthy, although I felt it started off a little slow. If you like Serious Sam type shooters, which this game references heavily to, this is your jam!

reviewText:
What to say first about this amazing game? This is some of the most fun I've ever had playing an FPS game - that's what Shadow Warrior is from start to finish: pure fun.

You play as Lo Wang, an assassin sent on a seemingly menial task, until things get completely out of hand with a full blown demonic invasion. Lo Wang and the witty and insightful deuteragonist Hoji, are a delight to listen and their personalities complement each other's perfectly, constantly exchanging light hearted, hilarious quips and wisecracks, but also being serious when circumstances demand. They are a match made in heaven - or hell, in this case. You can't help but chuckle when you listen to them. The story is inspired by old Asian legends and is surprisingly good. It doesn't make much sense at first but things get tied together rather nicely towards the end.

The combat (which you'll be doing a LOT of) is extremely satisfying and gory. The hectic, always-mobile nature of the fights will keep you to the edge of your seat, especially in the endgame chaotic battles. The gradual introduction of new enemies and weapons keep things interesting. Use variety in your kills and you'll be rewarded extra Karma points, which give you access to a detailed skill tree that you can customize according to your playstyle. This encouragement to use variety lends an almost cinematic quality to some fights, reminiscent of Hong Kong cinema. There are plenty of cool weapons to select from, which can be upgraded with modifications you can buy throughout the game with such over the top options as to add a grenade launcher to your flamethrower, among others.

The levels are beautifully designed, with varying locales each gorgeous in its own right. The scenery is so nice that you can't help but think at times that you're looking at a postcard - albeit one with pools of blood and dead bodies littered about. It is not always obvious where to go and you might get lost at times, but try to get to the glowing" door and you'll be alright. Secrets are creatively hidden
date: and there are references to the old Shadow Warrior and other titles scattered all over the place.\n\nLast but not least - I did not encounter a single bug during my playthrough

reviewText:
I can't have enough words to describe this game.

It's one of those cases when you can't decide what to start a review with, because you are filled up with emotions. But there needs to be something, so I'll try to be informative now:
+ Graphics are amazing. Every location looks stylish and has a lot of details.
+ Combat feel awesome. It has the good old-school feeling to it. Whether you wield a katana to chop some meat to bloody pieces or just like to shoot baddies from far - it all will feel very intense and satisfying. I really like the presence of alternative modes for shooting weapons. It's something that I missed in shooters long time (screw you, Press RMB to aim"! Hail to the "Press RMB to kick ♥♥♥!").
+ You have 4 magic abilities and 4 sword powers. Those are activated by tapping the movement key twice and pressing LMB or RMB (you can use magic while wielding shooting weapons too). If it doesn't work well for you

reviewText:
Well with no doubt this was one of the biggest 2013 surprise, a FPS with lot of action, very different from what we are accustom. This one was a retro-reboot inspired on the Shadow Warrior released in 1997.

Here we control Lo Wang, a ninja mercenary from modern day time with excellent humor sense, we fight against demons hordes. Game is quite big, there are 17 large chapters, but linear levels with a good amount of secrets and easter eggs to discover.

Besides the good humor sense that game gives us, the combat system very smooth and is very varied, you have nice combos to make, with your sword or weapons.  You get a good number of weapons added to your arsenal as you progress through the game and can carry all of them with you. The combat also has a fantastic melee element with the katana that you start the game with.

We also have a progression and upgrade system, were we can upgrade our skills and get new powers with the KI crystals. When you upgrade the powers or the skills you can move faster, regenerate health easily or get a new power to Wang use.

Now the worst part of this game was definitely the gameplay, is very boring at least for me, we kill, we follow the goal that most of times is destroy a statue that is blocking a magical door and nothing else to do. Yeah we can find the easter eggs and some other secrets but still, i did expect more on this.

Overall I was surprised at how good this game was. If you are a fan of old-school, fast paced FPS action with a sense of humor then I highly recommend this game.

~ 7/10

reviewText:
I kind of expected that this was updated version of the old Shadow Warrior. I was positively surprised, this game doesn't rely on just nostalgia. There's plenty of nods to the original, but this is totally new game.

Serious Sam 3 (I haven't played the first two) might be close cousin to this game, but this one has better humor and tighter plot progression. Though I didn't finish Serious Sam, so comparison might not be totally accurate.

What you can expect is swordplay that's supported with skills that keep sword relevant during whole game. Also weapons can be upgraded.

Game is relatively linear, which makes it somewhat more frustrating when there's no good clues on where to go next. Though exploration is rewarded, mostly with just ammo and money, but sometimes with karma that will help gaining more skills. And of course fortune cookies!

I think I finished the game in about 20 hours. I did explore quite a lot, rushing through the game should be lot faster.

If you want to hunt achievements, you get to keep all skills and weapon upgrades on second replay. That makes it much easier to get achievements that depend on number of kills etc.

reviewText:
The ultimate Hack 'n' Slash.

This game is one hell of an adventure, and on it's hardest difficulty, it's a beast to conquer.

You'll find yourself wandering off into the trees and streets searching for small relics after you've slain a monsterous demon quite often, you'll try to think which guns are best to upgrade first, and wonder what powers are actually useful.

The game is very satisfying, massive blood flowing from decapitated demons, lots of loot, a fancy arsenal of weapons, and a whole lot more. The 3 boss fights in the game can take quite some time depending on the difficulty, but feel very rewarding after defeating them.

A crossbow that fires explosive detonating rounds? Why not? A shotgun that has a giant red button which allows you to shoot all bullets at once... why not?

The controls are very responsive, and with a mouse and keyboard, there are no problems at all. The scenery and buildings are textured and completed to look very realistic, the cliched cherry blossoms and temples are a perfect addition, and the endless amounts of comedy also helps.

After spilling a ridiculous amount of blood from decapitated demons and hilariously laughing at the dialogue, this game is perfect.

10/10

reviewText:
You may wonder if this game is good and the answer is YES. Remember playing DNF and wishing they would just copy the game formula and make a great game instead of making yet another abysmal monster with QTE, regen, weapon limit and idiotic vehicle levels.
Well, this game did remake job RIGHT.
If you loved those golden age of FPS games powered by the BUILD engine (ROTT, Redneck Rampage, DN3D, Powerslave, etc etc), you will really really enjoy the SW.

A few things I love the most:
* Almost everything can be destroyed / exploded.
* Three different upgrade systems (weapon upgrades, skill tree, separate ability tree with separate resource pool)
* ♥♥♥♥ING KATANA
* Classic free-to-explore level layouts with tons of secret places. (I wish I had that BUILD-style map overlay)
* Classic weapon set (Pistol, SMG, shotgun, boomsticks, etc) - no modern two weapon slots ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.
* Healthkits, no regen. (Well, technically there is regen, but it is tied to the skill system)

tl;dr - classical FPS with a remastered graphic that will make you cry in joy.

reviewText:
ATTENTION RISE OF THE TRIAD 2013 MAKERS, THIS IS HOW YOU ACTUALLY DO A GAME REBOOT RATHER THAN MAKE ONE OF THE BIGGEST PIECE OF CRAP DISAPPOINTMENTS EVER!

Being a massive Shadow Warrior fan, putting countless hours into the original game in SP and 1vs1 with a friend in MP over our 33.6k modems back in 1998, some very fond memories all around, and also reading two awesome full paperback novels based on the game, I was of course going into this with a very critical attitude and was ready to be disappointed. I figured that if the newer Rise of the Triad remake sucked so horribly, that there was no hope with this game. But it is a time for rejoicing because this is, thankfully, not what I was expecting.

This game looks, sounds, and plays beautifully. It is probably the best running, smoothest game I have ever seen which is pretty amazing. One of its high points is that it tells a very well written epic tale that was a pleasure to experience. Most games are not written nearly this well. Overall it has very high production value and looks outstanding. The sounds and music all sound superb and of the highest quality. The graphics are beautiful. The level design and layouts are done very well. The gameplay flows smooth as silk. The weapons are all awesome but the high point of the game is sword combat. It is the most well done, most fun sword combat I have ever seen in a game. Or at least ever in a FPS action game anyway. Melee combat in this game feels really good while in most other games they could not do melee combat right to save their ♥♥♥♥ing lives. You can even tap certain button combos to do awesome helpful sword skills once you unlock them (all moves are simply done by double tapping a single movement key then pressing LMB or RMB, like D, D, RMB).

One other thing I love in the game are the enemies. The deeper you get, there are new enemies and new boss fights. All of the enemies look very well done like a lot of time and care went into making these enemies as detailed as they are graphically. They also provide a good challenge on higher difficulty.

So where the newest Rise of the Triad was a complete failure of very poor performance, cheap and often times unavoidable deaths, bugs, boring/few enemy types, crap enemy ai, awful graphics, and really poor level design, this game is like a gift from heaven compared to that game and shares none of those issues. This game deserves a 9/10 in its own right.

reviewText: If you love the culture of the 80's hard body action genre, you will get a kick out of this absolute ♥♥♥♥ing masterpiece of gaming. It sits right up there with Doom and Wolfenstein with gratuitous amounts of gore, violence, and tongue-in-cheek humor. It's a wild ride: a bloody, demon-infested, sunglasses-indoors, sword-wielding ride you'll never forget.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Shadow Warrior is an ode to the old FPSes of the 90’s. There’s no waist high walls or the game yelling at you to get back to the combat zone;  just you, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of enemies, and an arsenal of weapons to use to blow them to kingdom come. Funny thing is though, you probably won’t be using your guns all that much because your katana is one of the best weapons you have and it’s a blast to use.  The game isn’t a cakewalk, you need to be  on your toes even on Normal. Normal has just the right kind of challenge for  a person familiar with FPSes but the real FPS thrill seekers have three higher difficulties to play with. It’s also fairly lengthy, most levels taking around an hour to complete, but it never feels like it overstays its welcome and the environments are changed up enough to stay interesting. The writing is purposely try hard and corny and its amusing because of that though it might not be for everyone. Despite all appearances though it actually has a solid plot for an FPS and it honestly ends up having some real heart. My only real complaint its that the load times are bad, probably because the game has such crazy high graphics. Overall Shadow Warrior is a must play if you love some fast paced hack, slash, and shooty goodness.

reviewText:
First 10 minutes of Shadow Warrior:

- I am singing along to ''the Touch'' by Stan Bush while driving a sports car
- I get out of the car at the most stereotypical Japanese garden you've ever seen
- I ask some dude about a sword I was going to buy from him
- Dude betrays me and sends his ninja henchmen at me
- I fight off the ninjas like I'm in that one scene from 'Kill Bill'
- I run after the dude who just betrayed me
- Dude gets killed by a random ♥♥♥ demon called 'Hoji'
- Hoji tells me the other demons took the sword and betrayed him so wants to help me get it back
- We get in my sports car and drive off to an epic adventure
Chapter 1 complete"

8/10 would become BFF's with a demon again"

reviewText:
YOU ARE TINY GRASSHOPPAH!

Surprisingly good remake of a classic game of the same genre. Action is tons of fun, puns are where they belong, and it also has an unexpected great story and characters.

Some scenarios may get a little dull after some time, but the sword fighting throughout the entire game is extremely addictive. There's also a leveling system where you may upgrade abilities and acquire special attacks, which motivates you to keep on exploring and killing demons to acquire the needed points.

Definitely recommend Shadow Warrior

reviewText:
A game like no other, and really brings the nostalgic feel of old school shooters and hack n' slash. Haven't played the original Shadow Warrior, though I have played old school shooters like doom and such so I anticipate its the same (please correct me if I'm wrong).

You are Lo Wang, a seemingly hard-skin individual able to withstand tons of bullets and giant demons in suit of armors with ease. With an arsenal of badarsey weaponry, you will go through a a journey slaying humans and demons alike in a campaign length of about 8 - 15 hours.

***PROS:****
The pros. Oh boy. This game really hits you in the head with its old school combat. With drawbacks to the original with fanservice, references and... naked anime girls? The game comes in with 3 skill-tree like interfaces, called Powers, Skills, and Weapons (though the weapons are more like upgrades) which are- in my opinion pretty cool and can make one's user experience easier (please see cons). You will hack and slash (or gun your way through, but to be honest, no one ever uses guns.. right? I hope.) through a multitude of enemy types. Lo Wang, the protagonist, throughout the game undergoes pretty evident character development, going from a brat and dumb to a pro and awesome. The environments are also VERY well made IMO, able to maneuver quickly and efficiently without much obstacles in your way (unless its a corridor then might as well use your guns and dual-akimbo that crud).

****CONS:****
Cons, eh. Like I said before, Powers, Skills and Weapons will make one's user experience much, and I mean, MUCH easier. I really do NOT recommend playing this game on Normal or easier as that will ruin the classic Shadow Warrior" experience. Besides
date: old school-like games are mean't to be played with a challenge

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game. Before it came out I was pretty worried about it. Mainly the price and the lack of 3D realms plus they didn't exactly lead an encouraging ad campaign. But the price was sorted out by good deals everywhere within a month of its release. I picked it up for 20 bucks on the humble store and it came with a DRM free copy. And after i got to play through it turned out to be one of my favorite games of 2013.


To start off. This is NOT a straight reboot like Serious Sam 3 or the new Rise of the Triad. Flying Wild Hog (Dev) really put their own spin on the game. The game has the sort of FPS\RPG aspect going on. With abilities and powers. as well you can upgrade your weapons to give them more damage output and if you have a bit of cash stored up you can upgrade them to have a secondary fire which can really change the way you use that weapon.

The thing that really caught me off guard about the game and what really made it stand out to me were the characters and story. Hoji was funny and likeable and Lo Wang was a real character now instead of a joke like in the original. (Not to bag on Shadow Warrior.)

The story that you follow is actually prety interesting too. As far as video games go at least. without being 'spoilery', I must say. The way the story goes toward the end will suprise you. They break off from the silly part of the game at the end there to bring you a real conclusion to the story. And I think the ending alone will always make this game stand out to me.


To wrap things up. The gameplay itself is as fun and challenging as you would want and with the skills, powers and upgrades you can take many different approaches to the game and play your own way.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent graphics, music and gameplay. Didnt have this much fun with melee combat since Dark Messiah of M&M (you will want
and you will spend 90% of time wielding katana Nobitsura Kage), ranged weapons are also interesting (demon head for the win).
Combat is extremely bloody and fun (especially chopping enemies with katana), but also challenging (when fighting swarm of
enemies). Story is also interesting with crazy twists. There are even three separate categories of upgrades (weapons,powers and skills)
Maps are worth exploring (there are lots of easter eggs and hidden levels and locations).SW especially shines when it comes to humor
(dialogues between Lo Wang and Hoji are memorable, Lo Wang's one-liners mocking almost everything are hillarious, fortune cookies, parodies...).
You thought Duke Nukem and Dante are cool jerks with crazy comments? You haven't met Lo Wang.
This game is fantastic...I mean Wangtastic.
And whatever you do, early in the game...DON'T ATTACK CUTE BUNNIES FOR YOUR OWN GOOD!

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior appears to be (arguably) the best swordplay game out there on the market. I craved for a shooter, but apparently katana's way is so much better! Every non-boss enemy in the game could be defeated with the sword only, even when they teleport on you in big numbers. No big deal — there is always a way to cut poor beggars heads off due to your greater mobility, ki-strikes and self-healing skills. Once you've invested into some Katana Mastery points, the game becomes hectic first person slasher like nothing else. Somehow, the whole game is balanced around beheading your enemies. (Bosses are unlike that though, there is a different gameplay for them to switch your pace.)

Quick snapshot of your further experience with this game: you are below half of your health, dashing like a maniac between blooming sakura trees with your sword drawn, a dozen of lesser demons are running you down, while a pair of greater demons shoot green fireballs at you from afar. Gathering strength for the self-healing ki-strike you bash your way into the midst of the enraged horde: there is a smile on your face.

In addition, Chinese cookies are delicious in this game. Would be such a waste if you don’t try them.

reviewText:
I only played this game for 2 hours, and it was only survival mode.

But I don't need to play it any further to know that this game is ♥♥♥♥ing fun and akin to Serious Sam and other classic titles of the 90's. It's real effin colorful too and forgoes the realistic black and brown plague of recent ''trouble in a Middle-Eastern town'' shooters. Or, god forbid, the blue hue of Battlefield 3, which I just don't get.

Actually, I'll update this later when I fully get to the game, but I already know it's gonna be awesome. I'm excited enough for it that I'll recommend it based on first impressions alone.

------
edit- I was right. It pretty much IS ''Serious Sam with Lo Wang'', the basic level progression is moving forward, encountering several enemies you have to take out, and proceeding with story scenes thrown here and there in the middle or towards the end of the level. Story scenes are kept succinct, obviously.

One thing this game has that Serious Sam (or any other FPS title) doesn't have is fleshed out melee mechanics. Any other title and the melee weapon is merely a last resort for when you run out of ammo; ♥♥♥♥♥♥, slow, low damage output, and unwanted. Shadow Warrior made it so that your melee is versatile and preferable to long-range weapons. Don't get me wrong, sticky bombs on a crossbow and firing off 6 shotgun shells simultaneously is fun, but you have a dash that lets you get up to your enemies really quickly. You also have a sword technique to impale, to spin 360 degrees and clear out people around you, and to release a long range energy burst. Coupled with your healing technique you'll be dashing into enemies and clearing out waves, pulling back to heal (4 second heal time) and quickly rushing back in.

In fact, I think its fair to say that the developers wanted you to mainly stick to your sword, since theres a level-up system that requires cash, and you might wanna forego buying ammo for weapons to scrougne up the funds to add bombs to your crossbow or to have auto-fire on your revolver. Which means that you'll only ever use your guns when you have the ammo to spare, to take out those annoying flying enemies, or when facing the larger enemies that really damage you if you stay close to them for long.

Hell, I'll call this a first person hack and slash, or a FPS title-First Person Slicer. Witty, I know. There's nothing wrong with the guns, and the upgrades are REALLY worth it and make them incredibly fun. But the attention paid to melee makes this game really unique, and there's something satisfying about having your screen fill with blood and seeing a crowd of ghoulish faces up close rather than taking them out from afar. Your slashes and dashes are arguably more enjoyable than killing people from 15 feet away.

I guess there are some downsides. Weapons are found as you progress with the game, rather than pickups in levels. So you don't get to enjoy the flamethrower until you're deeper into the game. Also, some enemy variety in attack patterns would make combat a little more tactical and less of a 'mow ♥♥♥♥ down' fest. There's the aformentioned bomb enemy, and those flying dudes that become a target range. But it still feels like there could've been more. Let me see...the environments and enemies look good, but some of the character models in cut scenes look a little low-tier, but its an FPS title so who cares. When I'm finding myself trying to pick negatives rather than them coming immediately to mind that means its a good game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I must recommend this game. It turned out to be much better than I expected, based on the promo videos. SW is a fun action game that is best for melee attacks. If you like Dead Island for melee (like I do), you’ll love Shadow Warrior. That katana is awesome. Guns too, especially later in the game. Purchase the dual-wielding option for the mini submachine gun. Buildup your character (Lo Wang) as the game progresses. Gather money for weapons upgrades, Ki crystals for powers, and karma points for skills. Although the game has lots of light banter, the underlying story is rich and serious indeed, if a bit confusing. This was a surprising and pleasing discovery. It helped motivate me thorough what begins to be a grind of arena battles, of which there are many, many.

Bosses are enormous giants. Boss fights are doable and not too hard. Just remember to heal yourself frequently, circle to pick up powerups and shoot for the weak points when they appear. The “powers” must be invoked by keyboard/mouse combos. This can be a bit of a problem because it takes a bit of doing to remember them and invoke them when you need them most – during a battle.

Map landscapes and architecture are very detailed and often beautifully done. Shadow world maps are sparse. Game was rock solid – stable movement throughout, no crashes or glitches, never got stuck, frequent checkpoints.

I would give this game 85/100 for action, story, artistic presentation, and sheer fun.

reviewText:
Excellent graphics, music and gameplay. Didnt have this much fun with melee combat since Dark Messiah of M&M (you will want
and you will spend 90% of time wielding katana Nobitsura Kage), ranged weapons are also interesting (demon head for the win).
Combat is extremely bloody and fun (especially chopping enemies with katana), but also challenging (when fighting swarm of
enemies). Story is also interesting with crazy twists. There are even three separate categories of upgrades (weapons,powers and skills)
Maps are worth exploring (there are lots of easter eggs and hidden levels and locations).SW especially shines when it comes to humor
(dialogues between Lo Wang and Hoji are memorable, Lo Wang's one-liners mocking almost everything are hillarious, fortune cookies, parodies...).
You thought Duke Nukem and Dante are cool jerks with crazy comments? You haven't met Lo Wang.
This game is fantastic...I mean Wangtastic.
And whatever you do, early in the game...DON'T ATTACK CUTE BUNNIES FOR YOUR OWN GOOD!

reviewText: First, let me start off by saying that I grew up with the original Shadow Warrior (and many of the old build engine games) as some of my favorite games when I was younger. I have many, many fond memories of that/those games. So when I first heard that they were rebooting it, I was a little hesitant. However, then I heard that Flying Wild Hogs was at the helm and I felt a little better. However, I also was worried that the racial stuff (which in many ways made the original what it was) would not be present due to the climate of today’s society... and quite frankly, rightfully so. Many of those racial things in the original were extreme and highly racist, so they really have no place in a modern intelligent game. Anyway, I am pleased to say that they did away with the racist stuff and improved on almost every aspect of the Shadow Warrior universe. The combat and controls are tight. The guns are amazing. The enemies are relentless. The core mechanics are awesome. But at the forefront is the swordplay. The Katana is no longer just a melee weapon that you use when you run out of bullets. It is the star of the show. I would argue that it is second main character of the whole game. If you liked hard reset, you will love this game. If you like Japanese culture, you will love this game. If you love great single player, story driven FPS's, you will absolutely love this game! Buy, buy BUY!!!

reviewText: Any game that opens with Stan Bush’s “The Touch” is off to a good start.  The game that follows the extremely well done opening is a well-made love letter to 90’s first person shooters.  The campaign is meaty and substantial with a liberal helping of humor and some Big Trouble in Little China flavoring.  I fully recommend it.

reviewText: This game was a no-frills early 90s shooter reborn. Not much for flashy cinematics or crazy depth, it tells a fairly decent, albiet confusing at times, story of Lo Wang, your protagonist with an off-colour mouth, and his demoic sidekick. The dialogue between them two is honestly genuinely funny, and between waves of various demons and monsters, it's placed out pretty well. The variety of powers, weapons and attacks you can use is pretty lengthy. Upgrades to all of them are available as well, and offers a pretty solid action package with secrets and moderate replayability, and a healthy campaign length.\n\nAs a fan of the early 90s shooters, I loved this remake, though I didn't play the original. At times challenging, a few levels a bit long, but fun weapons, enemies and abilities, I'd definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is a reboot of the older Shadow Warrior, released back in 1997 and then was remasted in 2012 to Shadow Warrior Redux and along came this game and all I have to say is It's f***ing awesome!

So story, the basics of the story is that you are Lo Wang, a man who is trying to buy a sword for his contact. Lo Wang's boss wanted a precious sword. When he talks to the owner of the sword, he says no. After that, things go south....FAST. Wang become a mass murdering, kitana welding foe for them. When exploring the palace for the sword, things go south again as you are captured by the owner of the sword and locked away. While all that happens, demons start to roam the earth, killing anyone in sight. You escape from the thing they call a prison and find out the owner of the sword died from a fire you have also fallen into. On the brink of death, you find out that the owner (I dont know his name) had a demon, trapped and banished to roam the earth, named Hoji. When you team up with him, you get abnormal powers such as healing. Other that the story is pretty bad.

But I don't think anyone is here for the story. The gameplay of this game is f***ing awesome. This game has a score system after every wave of enemies you kill in the area. With the karma points, as they are called, you can buy abilities and ability upgrades. The scoring system kinda works like Bulletstorm, the more the combo and people you kill with one action, the more points. It works really well with this game, it makes the game more exciting and makes you want to try to get better combos and see how many points you can get with one action. The store and shop to upgrade your guns is very limited, 4 attachments for each gun. There's a pistol, submachine gun, crossbow and many more that you unlock farther in the game.The gunplay in this game is good. I only say that because when you have a kitana that can cut people in as many bits as the game will let you, you want to use that. Using the kitana will give you hours of amusement. I said this but, It's like Fruit Ninja

column32: we need to talk about the weapons as well. Throughout the levels you will find money which you can either spend on ammo (don't ever do this!) or on weapon upgrades. Each weapon has an essential upgrade that will turn it into a great DPS dealer
column33: you will have to resort to in case you get overwhelmed by hoards of enemies. Unfortunately this means that all wepaons are utter trash unless you spend money to upgrade them.\n\nThe core shooter mechanics however
column34: is where this games shines. 95% of all enemies either use a projectile or melee attacks in order to deal damage to you. This means that there is no need to ever take any cover
column35: allowing you do keep track of all projectiles and dodging them accordingly. To help you with this
column36: the game allows you to jump in all four directions which adds a refreshing dynamic to the combat. To add to the challenge all enemies use a rather modern hit box system
column37: that allows you to shoot off limps in order to immobilize them. You need to stand still trying to aim for a the head of the on coming enemies

column43: as well as shooting projectiles towards you. He is a real bulletsponge and fighting him is the very antithesis of fun. This gets issue grows less and less important as your weapons grow more powerful and your skill increases. Keep in mind that I was playing on the "Hard" difficulty setting. The bigger problem are the bossfights. They stink. All of them use the same mechanic

which was a major letdown for me.

Story and Presentation:
SW 2013 tries to get rid of the "racist and misogynistic" humor of the original game
column47: replacing it with an emotional story. While the game manages to pull of the plot quite well
column48: you should under no circumstances except something like Bastion or The Walking Dead which leave you completely emotionally destroyed
column49: if you get emotionally invested with their respective characters. Shadow Warrior doesn't do this and leaves you indifferent at best towards the whole tragedy in which the games ends. Speaking of ending
column50: the more you advance the more unpolished and untested the game feels. The game builds up an epic confrontation with Zilla
column51: a Faustian villian who caused the invasion of the shadow realm onto the human word for his own needs. But instead of fighting him and adding some much needed variety to the bossfights
column52: you just face him (twice!) in a first person cutscene. The same applies to the leader of the shadow beings. How overwhelmingly disappointing. Heck
column53:
the final boss fight doesn't even have music like the others with makes it even more boring.

Technology:
The games is extremely resource demanding even on my 4770k/GTX 780 rig and does not look good enough in order to justify this. Instead it makes about every other object in a level explosive which unleashes a storm of death and physics across the screen. I also had some issue with the vsync
column54: that caused the FPS to drop to 30 once it went below 60
column56:
up to the point where I just disabled it end endured the screen tearing instead.

Verdict
Overall Shadow Warrior 2013 is a great indie shooter with solid gameplay and a disappointingly weak presentation that completely falls flat on its face near the end of the game. If you are a fan of games like Serious Sam or Painkiller
column57: this game is a must buy for you. But don't except a real 90's shooter
column58:
because it just isn't one.

The good
-Solid and fun gameplay

The bad
-Story and presentation fall completely flat towards the end.
-Resource intensive
-Terrible bossfights"

reviewText: Shadow Warrior initially tries really hard to make you think it's less wonderful than it is, but the conviction that the developers and voice artists exhibit in delivering such a crazy product allows it to pull off the lame jokes, pop culture references and mindless action with panache. And after you're convinced that you're playing a superficial action game with another vapid set of cliche characters, somewhere along the line after all the fan service and wisecracks and gore, you realise that you're invested in the story and you care about the characters, and suddenly you become aware of how shockingly well-made this game is.\n\nGiven the patchy success-rate of recent nostalgic reboots and reimaginings (I'm looking at you, ROTT), Shadow Warrior suprised the hell out of me with it's smooth and responsive controls, entertaining gameplay, beautiful visuals, and well-cast voice actors. It understands exactly what it wants to be at any given moment, and excels at both the early tongue-in-cheek schlock, as well as the later more serious character development. This is clearly a game in which all the talent behind the scenes really shines through, and I can't recommend it highly enough.

column18: since I usually got lost once the levels got too complex in later episodes of these types of games. Though I do have to point out
column19: that I still managed to get lost in these rather simplistic levels
column20: because I got stuck more then often without knowing what I had to do. This was mostly due to the fact that SW2013 Highlights usable items with an incredibly obnoxious glow effect that makes it easy to differentiate between geometry and usable entities. Since I am not a fan of these types of mechanics I played the game with the effect off
column21: which unfortunately resulted in me sometimes not being able to figure out what to do because the switch I was supposed to press just blended in with the scenery. That's the issue with these types of helpers. Even if you have the option to disable them
column22: game game is still designed with them in mind
column23:
making it unnecessarily complicated to discard them even if you want to.

Core Gameplay:
You are equipped with an arsenal of firearms as well as a Katana and an endless supply of underpowered Shurikens that drain your regenerating stamina meter as you throw them. Speaking of regeneration
column24: your health does not automatically regenerate. Instead there are medipacks and armor vets scattered throughout the levels. Despite that fact that there is no auto health regen
column25: you still have the ability to heal yourself in form of a Ki Power. Ki Powers are combos that you can pull of as a player by completing a sequence of actions. For instance
column26: to initiate your healing ability you press D twice in a row and then press Mouse2
column27: holding it down. Most KI Powers either give you crowd control over enemies
column28: or new moves with your Katana.\n\nThroughout the game the play can find KI Crystals that allow him to upgrade or unlock powers. Speaking of Upgrading there are two other kinds of progression. The first one is the Karma system. If you use a wide variety of skills and weapons to kill of enemies
column29: you are rewarded with Karma points that you can spend to level up various stats
column30: such as your maximum health as well as the amount of damage you deal to certain types of enemies. How ever
column31: by doing so you will cause some enemies to enter their rage form which makes them more aggressive and dangerous.\n\nIf we are talking about damage dealing
column32: we need to talk about the weapons as well. Throughout the levels you will find money which you can either spend on ammo (don't ever do this!) or on weapon upgrades. Each weapon has an essential upgrade that will turn it into a great DPS dealer
column33: you will have to resort to in case you get overwhelmed by hoards of enemies. Unfortunately this means that all wepaons are utter trash unless you spend money to upgrade them.\n\nThe core shooter mechanics however
column34: is where this games shines. 95% of all enemies either use a projectile or melee attacks in order to deal damage to you. This means that there is no need to ever take any cover
column35: allowing you do keep track of all projectiles and dodging them accordingly. To help you with this
column36: the game allows you to jump in all four directions which adds a refreshing dynamic to the combat. To add to the challenge all enemies use a rather modern hit box system
column37: that allows you to shoot off limps in order to immobilize them. You need to stand still trying to aim for a the head of the on coming enemies
column38: pull the trigger and then do a quick jump to the left or right
column39: to avoid the amount of stuff that comes flying towards you
column40: ready to explode in your face. That being said
column41: the shooting has its weaknesses though
column42: especially concerning the stronger enemy types. There is one in particular that really grind me gears: The Shaman is a so called "greater demon" or mini boss that frequently shows up raising an infinite army of undead enemies
column43: as well as shooting projectiles towards you. He is a real bulletsponge and fighting him is the very antithesis of fun. This gets issue grows less and less important as your weapons grow more powerful and your skill increases. Keep in mind that I was playing on the "Hard" difficulty setting. The bigger problem are the bossfights. They stink. All of them use the same mechanic
column44: which is extremely tiresome and boring. Even though all bosses use a slightly different attack pattern
column45: you feel like you are fighting the same boss over and over again. This is no different concerning the final boss
column46:
which was a major letdown for me.

Story and Presentation:
SW 2013 tries to get rid of the "racist and misogynistic" humor of the original game
column47: replacing it with an emotional story. While the game manages to pull of the plot quite well
column48: you should under no circumstances except something like Bastion or The Walking Dead which leave you completely emotionally destroyed
column49: if you get emotionally invested with their respective characters. Shadow Warrior doesn't do this and leaves you indifferent at best towards the whole tragedy in which the games ends. Speaking of ending
column50: the more you advance the more unpolished and untested the game feels. The game builds up an epic confrontation with Zilla
column51: a Faustian villian who caused the invasion of the shadow realm onto the human word for his own needs. But instead of fighting him and adding some much needed variety to the bossfights
column52: you just face him (twice!) in a first person cutscene. The same applies to the leader of the shadow beings. How overwhelmingly disappointing. Heck
column53:
the final boss fight doesn't even have music like the others with makes it even more boring.

Technology:
The games is extremely resource demanding even on my 4770k/GTX 780 rig and does not look good enough in order to justify this. Instead it makes about every other object in a level explosive which unleashes a storm of death and physics across the screen. I also had some issue with the vsync
column54: that caused the FPS to drop to 30 once it went below 60
column56:
up to the point where I just disabled it end endured the screen tearing instead.

Verdict
Overall Shadow Warrior 2013 is a great indie shooter with solid gameplay and a disappointingly weak presentation that completely falls flat on its face near the end of the game. If you are a fan of games like Serious Sam or Painkiller
column57: this game is a must buy for you. But don't except a real 90's shooter
column58:
because it just isn't one.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The good
-Solid and fun gameplay
-Combat based on projectile avoidance and strafing

The bad
-Story and presentation fall completely flat towards the end.
-Resource intensive
-Terrible bossfights"

reviewText: I have played about 5 hours of this game and the last couple of hours felt like an eternity. You start of interested and engaged. The swordplay is something I have never seen before and the first couple of hours you get some nice story bits and you progress quickly in terms of new weapons, getting new skills and seeing new enemies. But after a couple of chapters you go through a corridor enter a big room and see the same enemies. Then you walk through the next corridor and enter a big area with the same enemies. I was getting 1 or 2 funny lines from Wang for every 100 boring enemies I had to kill. I played shooters like Wolfenstein the New Order where I forgot what I was doing, because the story was so interesting. Here you walk through rooms to get to the next enemies and I have no motivation to finish this game.\n\nP.S. thats just my opinion. If you can make your own fun with pretty flashy, repetitive combat then buy it I guess. I got it on steam sale and its fine for the couple of hours I played.

reviewText:
Why should you buy Shadow Warrior?

Two words: level design.

I know that sounds like an odd reason, but for me it's the games greatest strength. Visit my profile page and go through my screenshots. The game is GORGEOUS.

So what about the rest of the game? Well from a long time and avid player of the FPS genera, it's a mixed bag. I played the game twice all the way through. Once on normal" difficulty and then again on "insane". On normal I used the Katana the entire time. That was probably stupid
date:
but the melee combat felt extremely satisfying. The Ki powers were also a blast to use. That wore off about 8 hours into the game. Little did I know there's 8 more hours to grind through. I got that feeling of: "Is this over yet?"

Well after some consideration I felt like I should give the game another try. My inner achievement hunter had something to do with it too! :-)

The second time I went with insane mode and used all the weapons. With the inclusion of the 1.5 optimization patch the game looked and ran better than ever. However
recommended: the weapons felt weak. Extremely weak. Even the bad-♥♥♥ looking quad barreled shotgun. Once I got my hands on the crossbow and the its chargeable shot upgrade
hoursPlayed: the game became cake. With fully upgraded healing powers and the one shot crossbow
voteText:
yet again I got that feeling of boredom.

So why am I recommending this game after calling it boring? Because it's like a really pretty bowl of oatmeal. There really isn't anything "wrong" with the game. It just middle of the road with a great number of sights to see.

My main gripe with Shadow Warrior is it tries to please everyone at the same time. The attempt of fusing old school and new doesn't seem to work for me. The game contains the Bioshock "Look everywhere for cash" loot system. It also has RPG elements
helpfulPercent: unlockables
votesHelpful: and a low assortment of opponent's to kill. My opinion is if you going to make a FPS
votesTotal:
choose a school and stick with it.

Pro's +

+++ Level Design + A huge range of environment's and aesthetics to enjoy! So many sights to behold!
+ Optimized + Looks great and runs really well!
+ Characters + The chemistry between Low Wang and his demon friend is quite entertaining.
+ Story + Easy to follow and keeps your interest.
+ Arsenal + Large variety of weapons and powers to make combat interesting - for a time...
+ Melee Combat + The Katana is really fun to play with!
+ Secrets + A must for any FPS.
+ EX Mode + Allows you to keep all your upgrades after you beat the game.

Con's -

- Enemies - Offers a limited amount of baddies to slay.
- Unbalanced Weapons - On the highest difficulty some of the weapons are pretty weak.
- Loot - If you want your weapons to have additional features
votesFunny:
you better look EVERYWHERE for cash.
- Game Length - Game progression is entirely "gated". Everything is locked until you kill each wave of enemies.

Shadow Warrior goes on sale frequently at 75% off. Well worth it at that price. If your playing for the first time
commentsCount: play the game on either easy or normal. Don't do what I did
column16: use all the weapon's in the game!"

reviewText: I tend to think remakes are the doodie but this game is pretty damn cool.  Cheesy dialogue, awesome melee combat, and pretty great visuals drive the story along for one of the best old school style experiences I've had in a while.  If you ever wanted to play as an asian dude named Lo Wang, collect statues, crystals, and pools of blood to upgrade your skill and powers while quartering every adversary you come into contact with on your quest for a sword, then this is for you.  Honestly, this game is worth full price but if it's on sale and you don't buy it, you're ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Not disabled.  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: Devolver really knows how to make great games! This one really surprised me. The premise made it looks like a hack n slash / fps but this story has some real depth to it. The game plays a little like serious sam but there are elements that are so much better although somewhat an easier game. The story is really unique, funny, with a wide caste of characters and level designs. The guns are really good, plus you use all of them pretty equally except the flame thrower. The combat system is really fun with a great upgrade system along side it. I'm also glad that the game is actually quite long which is always a plus. So glad I bought this during the christmas sale, I was not dissapointed! You should definitly play this game! You will not regret it!

reviewText: Make Senpai notice you in this balls to the wall hack-and-slash shooter extravaganza. You will be feeling kawaii as ♥♥♥♥ after playing this game because let's face it, who the hell doesn't want to be a god damn samurai? Mormons, that's who. While the gunplay is fun, where the game really shines is its swordplay, which is extremely satisfying and probably stands alongside Metal Gear Rising in terms of great sword fighting games that provide sheer enjoyment. The dialogue is surprisingly hilarious and some of the funniest material I have heard in a game in ages, which is an awesome surprise that I wasn't expecting at all. As far as the protagonist, Lo Wang is probably the most badass asian since Wei Shen or Bruce Lee.\n\nIn short, I would definitely recommend trying all the things seen in this game at home, because while I haven't myself, they look freaking amazing and a hell of a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Great game. Good fun combat and very robust upgrade system, but the story alone is worth it. It has a good ending that brings closure but also gives you something to think about. Shadow Warrior is a tale of sacrifice and tragedy; it is about the price of ambition and ramifications of forbidden feelings. What does it mean to be alive? The Ancients' memories can reveal all to you. Shadow Warrior pulls a rabbit out of the hat and the game makes it fly beautifully.

One of the best games I have played this year.

Think about things from the POV of the demons and every characters in the game when you finish it. I won't spoil anything. When you do that, in addition to all your insights, answer me this:

Did anyone, including Lo Wang, really had any choice in the game?

Think about your fun when you slice demons open too.

Maybe it doesn't have the same delivery style, but Shadow Warrior plot has some theme in Dark Souls.

reviewText:
Wow, okay, this is a shocker.

I'm first gonna give off a warning that I reccomend buying this when it's for an absolute steal, this game can go on sale for 5 dollars for the special edition that includes a bit more content, compared to the 40+ dollars non-sale price, however, if you want to show support for the developers, purchase the game in full, this game is just incredible, and feels more like a 60 dollar Triple A game done right.

Shadow Warrior is a game set within a stereotypical China, this game is heavily influenced from cheesy Japanese movies, and I love every second of it, this story keeps you entertained and invested as you travel to wildly different locales from a Japanese graveyard to a Tanker ship and watch the plot unfold, it has all sorts of cheese, including a very memorable protagonist in Lo Wang, who has a relatively stereotypical voice that is still interesting to listen to, especially in conversations with his demon buddy, Hoji. The gameplay is hands down the best part of this, Shadow Warrior makes itself different with it's star-based system that rewards you with extra Karma(Basically experience points) based on how well you kick Demon ♥♥♥, I've gone through over 10 chapters and haven't gotten a single 5-star, but this is motivation for me to try harder and hopefully get better to the point I get that 5 star. Thrown in is the best sword in any FPS ever, the player's Katana is the most versatile tool the player has, and it naturally upgrades over time as you continue the story, it can do powerful bursts of damage, an area swing, and one of those fancy air slashes that can mow down groups of enemies chasing you.

Hopefully I didn't overwrite stuff, or missed small details, but I can go on and on about why I think this is an excellent game and one of the best purchases I made in a while. Please, buy it, maybe even buy it while it's full priced to show the developers some love.

This is seriously what Duke Nukem should've been...minus the sword, and uh...less Shadow Warrior, more Duke.

reviewText:
Very good FPS (that is, First Person **Slasher** - also features some quite good gunplay in case that's your thing ;-)

This has to be the most rediculously pretty game ever - you start amongst Japan's famous Cherry Blossoms and the beauty keeps up the whole way through (unlike numerous other games). I played it in 3D, which just made everything all the more beautiful.

I wasn't into the story of this one so much (a lot of it just went over my head to be honest), but that gameplay was very refreshing and more than made up for it - it brings all the best parts of old school shooters without the all the baggage.

It also brings some extremely satisfying swordplay to the table - quite possibly the best we have ever experienced in a video game and easily my favourite means of dispatching enemies outside of boss fights.

It doesn't matter if you have played the original or not (the original is free btw), if you have played the original there is plenty of homage to be found - the anime girls are back (completely unchanged) and there are even a couple of secret areas straight out of the original (like Lo Wang's Dojo of Death from level 1, or the Dark Woods from later in the game). If you haven't played the original, don't worry - this game easily stands by itself, you'll just miss a couple of references (like why there are rabbits everywhere - oh yeah, the no ordinary rabbit" is back - kinda...).


I have to give it bonus points for having zero rendering artefacts with nVidia 3D Vision and a crosshair that's actually usable in 3D (i.e. positioned some distance into the scene)! I won't be uploading any screenshots (other than the glitch shots I already uploaded) since they're all in 3D and I don't particularly feel like converting and importing them to Steam. Just check the community hub if you want to see some screenshots ;)"

reviewText:
Overall Rating: 7/10

Shadow Warrior is a very good FPS, combining solid gunplay with great melee combat. The heavy melee focus sets it apart from similar games like Serious Sam or the Painkiller series, while you try to keep your distance from enemies in most shooters, here you will seek close contact much more often.

The levels are large and despite there being only one linear path to actually progress, there is always lots of secrets and pick-ups hidden in dark corners. Some might complain, that the lack of a mini-map or any kind of quest-marker makes it hard to know where to go sometimes, even when losing your way chances are high that you find at least something helpful or funny along the way.

Fun is something the game emphasizes a lot, the story is light, but the dialogs present range from cheeky to hilarious. There are three main settings, and the graphics are still great, especially the lighting is impressive throughout. Some bad textures and a couple of boring industrial areas in the second act dimish the overall good visual impression.

The only real downside to the game is the lack of enemy variety, since Shadow Warrior follows in Painkiller and Serious Sam’s footsteps of offering large scale battles and seemingly endless waves of enemies, there should be more enemy types to mix things up a bit better. As a result it is recommended to play this game not in long sessions but one or two levels a day. This way it keeps fresh and entertaining.

Pro:
- fantastic swordplay
- good variety of useful guns
- Full of pop-culture jokes
- solid upgrade system
- beautiful lighting and settings

Cons:
- not enough enemy variety
- some boring levels
- easy to get lost in the larger levels

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is jam-packed with epic fighting moves and fantastical powers, but you'll always find yourself being challenged. After the opening section of the game, weaker foes will fall before you with ease, but their tougher comrades aren't going to let you off the hook. However, this can be both a blessing and a curse.

Constantly challenging enemies serve an important purpose in gaming: they keep the difficulty from dropping so low that the game ceases to be interesting. At the same time, however, this can lead you as a player to feel like you're never improving as you progress. Shadow Warrior unfortunately falls into this category from time to time. New sword techniques will always look and feel impressive when you first learn them, but eventually it will start to seem as though your enemies are shrugging them off with little effort.

Similarly, the gun combat sometimes feels downright neglected compared to the swordplay. There are weapon upgrades and a few relevant skills, but the absence of anything resembling gun-kata makes firearms feel like somewhat overgrown support tools rather than their own beasts.

Despite the above criticism, however, Shadow Warrior is still a greatly entertaining experience. Although the guns aren't as interesting as the sword, few games allow you to slice and shoot quite as fluidly as this one.

reviewText:
So, what you expect?

You will have katana to cut monsters, you will have explosive barrels to shoot. Yes, when you enter a big room, after you press the button, monsters will pour out every damn corner. You can do cool magic stuff. You will have boss fights, with monsters ten times the size of you. There will be blood, bunnies and secret areas. Weapons, money to collect, skills to improve. Easter eggs. Cars to explode with one shot, corridors and health packs and ammuniton to pick up just from the ground. Mounted guns to maw waves of demons.

And you will have the adrenaline, the fun, and one good game just for casual fun and the satisfaction, when you empty a full magazine on one ugly creep.

Retro is back, pick your guns and bring it on, boyo.
