reviewText:
An excellent old school FPS for those who like fast paced action, huge and detailed levels with lots of stuff to find and a very solid slasher gameplay.
The story is a bit dull at times but holds rather well for a game that type, the humour is most of the time rather spot on and cutting demons in half (or more bits) doesn't fail to amuse over the course of the campaign.

I'd love to see more FPS like this one out there and less modern military shooters with played out mechanics and scripted events around the clock.

Excellent game with exceptionally fun melee. reviewText: An absolutely fantastic game, a must-have for any FPS enthusiast. Shadow Warrior has it all: great graphics, awesome weapons, blood-pumping soundtrack, fast-paced action, hidden collectibles, one-liners, and a surprisingly good sense of humor. Even with the fast-paced combat, explosions, and the hail of bullets you'll be sending towards the enemy, that's not the best part. The best part of Shadow Warrior is the sword-play which combined with the supernatural powers you get is done surprisingly well. The game has great features such as a quick-slash, shuriken throwing, and consumable weapons like the demon head and heart. To keep things interesting, all weapons are upgradeable adn so are your powers. Even with all of the solid aspects of the game, it goes above and beyond with things that most games would have left out such as equippable skins for your sword, an ultra-hard final difficulty, new game plus, an arena mode, fortune cookies, and fully destructable bicycles.

reviewText:
I’d almost forgotten what fun was like, and then Shadow Warrior came along. From the very first bars of the opening song, I knew that Flying Wild Hog (the developers) had made a game for someone like me.

Flying Wild Hog got The Touch.

That was worth the £20 right there. Just to know that someone recognised the demographic even existed. The rest of the game? The exact same message – “we know you exist, we know what you enjoy, and we’re just like you”.

The humour hits just the right level of stupid, and the game itself is just so damn good it makes up for the occasional lapses.

The combat is slick. There's no grinding, no pointless backtracking, no juggling three different economies for the sake of it, no trans-media experience required for optimal progression"

reviewText:
I liked the original Shadow Warrior quite a lot, it's a game that's fond to me since I grew up playing it, so seeing news of a new re-imagined game usually ends up being bad news, luckly this isn't the case here. Flying Wild Hog did a good job modernizing the core concepts and retaining or making various nods to the original.

The main concern for fans when this got announced was that old pervy Lo Wang was nowhere to be found being replaced by a younger Lo Wang. While it is true that this is a re-imagining, the story nearly serves as a prequel to the classic Shadow Warrior, I won't say much as to not spoil the story, suffice to say that while starting off being silly there's a surprisingly good story that unfolds in a rather sneaky manner as the game progresses, the developers truly delivered on the promise of a better story, only don't expect it to be all out exagerated parody of cliches like Duke Nukem 3D and the Classic Shadow Warrior were. There is a good deal of humour but it's not the main focus.

Visuals are for the most part gorgeous, the scenery is colorful and varied with a mainly Japanese aesthetic, only problem I found was that the later levels end up getting a bit repetitive but the overall art direction is quite beautiful.
Most of the enemies come in a nice variety, visually the lesser demons will have some acessories to set them apart but it won't affect much how you'll dispatch them, the humam enemies end up being the most unimpressive looking, but luckily there aren't many humans after the first chapter.
The game's areas are mostly arenas tied up by a somewhat linear path the areas you fight are diverse in shapes and most of them include plenty of environmental hazards to use against your enemies, there's plenty of secrets to be found as well, most of them are cash, ammo and karma awards that ties into the upgrade system which I'll mention later in the review.

The sound design is also very good, guns sound really well and apropriate, you'll hear the demons screeching at you or grunting in pain once you slice them. The music ends up mostly being background noise but they serve their purpose, it doesn't quite stand out since it's mostly muffled by all the carnage that's going down.

Where the game truly shines is the gameplay, there's a lot to cover here. You'll still have point based health system and you'll still be able to have nearly ten weapons on you while you fight hordes on enemies. But there's a few twists involved, now you have access to magic that can either stun enemies, protect or heal you, but there are limitations that ends up balancing their use, like the healing power only regenerates a portion of your health, you'll still need medpacks to get it back to 100%. You can use the spells any time without needing to waiting for them to recharge, some may leave you vulnerable while casting while other might limit your attack options, overall the spells are nice but aside from healing I forgot that I had most of them during the fights.

Most of the weapons from the original game comes back in one way or another, you'll get a Revolver, Uzi, Crossbow, Shotgun, Flamethrower and Rocket Launcher though you'll only get them at specific points in the story with the Katana being a permanent weapon throughout the entire game.
The katana is a blast to use, while the damage isn't always the most realistic you'll still have a gratifying feeling once you chop down your enemies to bits and getting the extra attacks for the sword makes it really fun to use. Another comeback to the arsenal are the enemies body parts you can still get the lesser demon's Hearts as an one shot weapon to instantly kill a few smaller enemies in an area or chop off the Warlord's heads that shoot a fire stream. An upgrade system has also been included, which you'll spend the money you find to buy secondary fire modes, improvements or ammo for the main weapons.

After every fight you get ratings that evaluate how well you've fought, they seem to be mostly altered by the diversity of weapons used in a fight and how much of the environmental hazards you've used during said fights at the end you get awarded with Karma points depeding on your rating. When you have enough Karma you'll get skill points which mostly give passive upgrades or new sword attacks.
There's plenty of other upgrades which will have you searching every area, you have money for weapons, karma (You can also find demonic altars with bowls of blood) for passive upgrades and skills and Ki Crystals to learn new or upgrade your magic. It's a very diverse but simple system in place.

When it comes down to it I had a blast playing Shadow Warrior, it's a terrific throwback to the older style of FPS with a few modern twists while during the first playthru it felt a little easy the extra difficulties and Heroic mode add a greater challenge. This is an easy recommendation to make if you enjoy single-player shooters and got tired of playing linear corridor spectacle shooters.

P.S: Oh yeah, kill the bunnies after they get it on, you'll eventually get a surprise  ;)

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior came out of nowhere and blew my mind. It is the best single player FPS game I have played in a long time. The gameplay itself might get repetitive toward the end of the game, but the well written dialogue and great characters kept me interested.
Shadow Warrior is a reimagining of the 1997 game of the same name. Some things connecting this new game to the 1997 original is some similar naming of locations, the main character and the heavy use of katana as a melee weapon, but basically you are not missing anything if you haven't played the original or even know nothing about it.

Here are some additional scrabled thoughts about the game

What I liked
-The story, characters, voice acting, visuals and soundtrack.
-The story is a mix between drama and comedy. Usually this is a bad idea, but somehow Shadow Warrior makes the mood shifts enjoyable. One of the most important reasons as to why Shadow Warrior has such good characters is that they are a mix of dramatic and comedic traits, which makes them very approachable and human.
-Good enemy variety. Different weapons/techniques are also required to beat some of the harder enemies.
-Good weapon variety, and you can carry all the weapons at once without needing to swap. There's also a weapon upgrade system in place. The upgrades are kind of scarse, so it's always interesting to get one and the upgrades have real impact, and most of them are not like +5% accuracy"
date: but alternative firing modes and such.\n-Flow of the game. There's a good rhythm with the story bits
hoursPlayed: humour
voteText: serious moments

votesHelpful: so it is nicely paced in terms of when you can just shut the game and take a break or do something else entirely.\n-Melee combat. It has a melee combat system with some executable special moves. The moves are always just double tap a directional key and press LMB or RMB
votesTotal: but still it's fun to execute them.\n-It has this kind of (but not quite) hint system where you need to always use objects or doors that glow yellow. I thought it was much more pleasant than the reqular arrow or path that shows you exactly where you need to go. When there was not immediate in your face indication of where to go I found myself exploring and taking in the world a lot better than in

say BioShock Infinite.

What I didn't like
-The boss battles are all the same. You just dodge attacks and shoot at the glowing weak spot.
-Some of the chapters drag a bit

forcing you into huge arenas with multiple waves of spawning enemies.
-The combat in general starts to become a bit boring when you have first learned all the sword techiques and then learnt when and how to execute them. It starts to become a bit mundane when there is no new stuff to learn.

In conclusion it is in my opinion one of the best games of 2013

As you can see I have played Shadow Warrior for about 50 hrs for good reason, its fun as Hell. I have not played a game as bloody fun as this since Saint Row 4. I can't really fault anything in this game It's got amazing humour, fast paced shooting, fantastic katana mayhem, great music and It looks AMAZING, I literally haven't seen a game look this good on my computers specs ever. The only things that I can see that would make people dislike the game, is the humour which I personally love but I know there's some people who'd dislike it, and the rather repetitive story which I didn’t really pay attention to.

I highly suggest this game to any fans of the old style FPS or FPS fans in general looking for a heap of fun, I thought it was the best shooter of 2013 in fact it was my favourite PC game of 2013. If I had a choice of every shooter out right now I’d play this one still in 2014.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun, quite challenging, even sometimes pretty, pretty hard (at insane difficulty). I laughed at lot with this game, liked the plot, the history behind, the communication between the characters, the combat system, the combos, I really loved the crossbow. Hands down.

Even with that, I felt that sometimes the game was offering always the same, spawning mobs at certain times, at a determined locations, so you can tell when they will happen.
It would be awesome if enviromental explosives things did much more damage, because it was kinda hard to lure them and get the achievement for killing mobs with them (and keeping barrels and such intact until they were almost dead).
I was never running out of ammo, because you can get them almost everywhere and if not you can buy them, which is all the opposite to the original version of this game. Medikits are everywhere.
Boss fights are cool, but the mechanics don't change that much. They are hard, and will wipe you if you don't pay attention!

Don't get me wrong, this game is awesome, bought it when it was on sale, and I enjoyed it a lot.
If you want to spend around 18 hours in an unending killing spree of demons, and punishing the evil from here and beyond, this is your chance!

reviewText:
I shot a rabbit while it was getting busy with another...
It turned into a demon and killed me.11/10 would die again.

Serious Review:
If you think shooting and slashing demons with swords and explosive crossbow bolts while dashing away from charging demons sounds fun, this game is for you.
Shadow Warrior is the reboot from the classic 1997 Shadow Warrior made in the Duke Nukem 3D engine.
The reboot is filled with fast-paced, horde like combat. Allowing the player to  hack and slash body parts into pieces. The game doesn't like to take itself seriously like most shooters today and will occasionally throw funny jokes and easter eggs likely to make you stop and laugh. The dash system allows you to dash towards or away from the charging demons or fireballs raining from the sky.
The game begins with you and your sword which you will master as you progress. You slowly progress to different weapons as well as various attachments. This form of progression allows for you to fight the increasingly more difficult hordes of demons out to get you and left me interested in unlocking my next attachment or skill.
This game might not seem as good looking as crysis or metro but the atmosphere in levels like Lo Wang's (the main characters) secret cave or looking over the hills of the cemetery can leave you breathless.
Overall I had a great time playing Shadow Warrior and I can easily recommend it to anyone.

PROS:
Graphics
humor
gameplay
level design
progression style
CONS:
Only a semi-decent story
only 2-3 variants of enemy aesthetics per class
(there should be some sort of looks randomizer to make it feel like you have sliced the same demon twice in a row. This should be noted that this is a problem I have with many other games that involve you up close and personal with your target.)

reviewText: I played this masterpiece of a game with no knowledge of either the original or hard reset, and when i actually started playing i fell in love with the game by the first level. The combat is as satisfying as it is responsive and the katana's hit detection is probably the best i've ever seen in a video game (however special abilities are difficult to use at first), there is no weapon that you feel you won't like simply due to the fact that all of them have niche roles. The plot is interesting as well making mindless killing actually seem like your doing something meaningful however i won't talk too much about it due to spoilers. The game also has a surprisingly good sense of (especially considering the fact that the main character's name is essentially a ♥♥♥♥♥ joke). Lastly the world is absolutely beautiful (albeit it's no columbia from bioshock infinite)\n\nDispite all of that however, the game has a few game breaking AI glitches (like enemies hiding behind cover forever in a place the player can't reach) that make it impossible to advance due to the kill everything to advance" system that only works if it's well placed in games like castle crashers. Also as i mentoned earlier the abilities are hard to use at first due to minor control issues and the exploration can get pretty boring when you just want to kill everything in sight but there's nothing for you to kill. Another thing to note is the unbareable load times
date: it's worse than dead rising 2 in this respect.\n\nOverall i'd reccomend this game to anyone who likes good stories
hoursPlayed: non-serious games and good humour but can tolerate a few downsides that prevent this game being perfect"

reviewText: There was a lot of skepticism surrounding the news that 3D Realms' 1997 shooter Shadow Warrior would be re-imagined for 2013, not least because the original game faded into obscurity compared with other Build engine games and was really remembered only for its often tasteless humour. Happily, Polish developer Flying Wild Hog went back to the original and rather than slavishly remaking it, did a wonderful job in taking from it what worked and removing or radically re-imagining what didn't. The end result is a hectic, gorgeous-looking shooter in a classic style with just enough of a modern sensibility to make it feel fresh. The most crucial aspect of the game's success? It has what the classic '90s shooters had and what modern ones very rarely possess - personality.

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed my time with this. I find it astonishing that more people didn't snap it up during the last sale! The game is a wonderfully up-to-date dose of oldschool shooter goodness - the guns are excessive, the action is frantic, the gore is intense and IT. IS. GLORIOUS. :D The dialogue is wonderfully cheesy, as are the in game jokes, but it's all part of the charm, think Onimusha meets Duke Nukem - Oriental sensibilities and setting/daemonology with a ridiculously over the top protagonist who is in on the fact that the game is out to be fun. I highly recommend this, great for long time FPS fans and newcomers too!

reviewText:
Great game. Good fun combat and very robust upgrade system, but the story alone is worth it. It has a good ending that brings closure but also gives you something to think about. Shadow Warrior is a tale of sacrifice and tragedy; it is about the price of ambition and ramifications of forbidden feelings. What does it mean to be alive? The Ancients' memories can reveal all to you. Shadow Warrior pulls a rabbit out of the hat and the game makes it fly beautifully.

One of the best games I have played this year.

Think about things from the POV of the demons and every characters in the game when you finish it. I won't spoil anything. When you do that, in addition to all your insights, answer me this:

Did anyone, including Lo Wang, really had any choice in the game?

Think about your fun when you slice demons open too.

Maybe it doesn't have the same delivery style, but Shadow Warrior plot has some theme in Dark Souls.

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is a 3D hack-n-slash where you fend off thousands of demons while following blinking objectives. There is no mini-map, instead objectives are highlighted and blinking (doors & switches). The game has a few different difficulty settings. I played on casual and only died a couple of times due to gravity. The fights never seemed boring and I felt like I could still die if I wasn't careful. I can imagine some of the fights taking alot longer on a harder difficulty.

Overall, the gameplay is solid, the story is fun, and the length of the game is good. I don't think I will be re-playing this title for a few months or so but I do feel like I will come back to it again in the future.

If you can pick this game up on sale like I did, it will be totally worth it.

reviewText: I was never one to play the original Shadow Warrior, but I think this game captures the spirit of old school fps games with some neat twists. I would love for Flying Wild Hog to expand on the game a bit more, maybe create a more polished sequel, as I feel there were some bits and pieces of this game that felt unrealized or primarily unfinished. And the plot takes a surprising turn near the end. But in the grand scheme of it all these are minor gripes.\n\nWhere the game truly shines is in the combat. Not quite Serious Sam level, but still more than enough to keep things tense and exciting. The environments have some nice touches, and although the secrets aren't necessarily well hidden, it's more than enough for anyone who wants to take the time to look for them. Unlike other franchises that have rebooted, while forgetting what made them so enjoyable (looking at you Painkiller and Duke Nukem), Flying Wild Hog has not only revived an aging series, but they've done so with good design sensibility, and an explosion filled, blood soaked shoot fest that also happens to have some very satisfying swordplay. 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Just completed this game, took me a little more than 11 hours so I definitely got my moneys worth. Based on the original Shadow Warrior, which was made in 1997 by 3D Realms (responsible for classics such as Duke Nukem 3D, Blood and Rise of the Triad), it's not really an re-make... more like a re-imagination, a re-boot.

Playing as Lo Wang, hired by Zilla Enterprise to help it's owner find the legendary Nobitsura Kage, a mystical katana connected to ancient demons. Aided by a spirit named Hoji, the player travels back and forth between the real world and the shadow realm to find the three parts of the sword and... yeah, that's about it when it comes to story.

The weapon of choice in this game is the katana, it's so satisfying to run around and chop all the different enemies to small pieces with the sharp katana. Sure, you've got some standard weapons like revolver, machine gun and rocket launcher and to make it all complete you even get to upgrade Lo Wang with different abilites and powers, which comes in handy while fighting wave after wave of demons.

It's GREAT fun and I think this is one of the best FPS games released in some years, it's not like Call of Duty and Battlefield and all that other stuff, it does its own thing and that's why everyone who enjoys the FPS genre should buy it and gives this a chance.

reviewText:
Overall Rating: 7/10

Shadow Warrior is a very good FPS, combining solid gunplay with great melee combat. The heavy melee focus sets it apart from similar games like Serious Sam or the Painkiller series, while you try to keep your distance from enemies in most shooters, here you will seek close contact much more often.

The levels are large and despite there being only one linear path to actually progress, there is always lots of secrets and pick-ups hidden in dark corners. Some might complain, that the lack of a mini-map or any kind of quest-marker makes it hard to know where to go sometimes, even when losing your way chances are high that you find at least something helpful or funny along the way.

Fun is something the game emphasizes a lot, the story is light, but the dialogs present range from cheeky to hilarious. There are three main settings, and the graphics are still great, especially the lighting is impressive throughout. Some bad textures and a couple of boring industrial areas in the second act dimish the overall good visual impression.

The only real downside to the game is the lack of enemy variety, since Shadow Warrior follows in Painkiller and Serious Sam’s footsteps of offering large scale battles and seemingly endless waves of enemies, there should be more enemy types to mix things up a bit better. As a result it is recommended to play this game not in long sessions but one or two levels a day. This way it keeps fresh and entertaining.

Pro:
- fantastic swordplay
- good variety of useful guns
- Full of pop-culture jokes
- solid upgrade system
- beautiful lighting and settings

Cons:
- not enough enemy variety
- some boring levels
- easy to get lost in the larger levels

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is jam-packed with epic fighting moves and fantastical powers, but you'll always find yourself being challenged. After the opening section of the game, weaker foes will fall before you with ease, but their tougher comrades aren't going to let you off the hook. However, this can be both a blessing and a curse.

Constantly challenging enemies serve an important purpose in gaming: they keep the difficulty from dropping so low that the game ceases to be interesting. At the same time, however, this can lead you as a player to feel like you're never improving as you progress. Shadow Warrior unfortunately falls into this category from time to time. New sword techniques will always look and feel impressive when you first learn them, but eventually it will start to seem as though your enemies are shrugging them off with little effort.

Similarly, the gun combat sometimes feels downright neglected compared to the swordplay. There are weapon upgrades and a few relevant skills, but the absence of anything resembling gun-kata makes firearms feel like somewhat overgrown support tools rather than their own beasts.

Despite the above criticism, however, Shadow Warrior is still a greatly entertaining experience. Although the guns aren't as interesting as the sword, few games allow you to slice and shoot quite as fluidly as this one.

reviewText:
The best thing you can say about Shadow Warrior is that Flying Wild Hog team have come out victorious from a very steep challenge. Remaking one of 3D Realms cult games while introducing a combat system which mixes FPS weapons, swords and magic powers is quite an achievement. Many studios have tried in the past to spice up the usual monotony of FPS encounters and failed horribly.

Sensitive with its classic roots, the game offers many secrets to discover in each level, very well known weapons like the shotgun or the rocket launcher. On top of that funny dialogues and situations help to ease the tension of the combats. In the 90's many FPS didn't take themselves too seriously so reliving some of that careless attitude is welcome here.

Another aspect which has been faithful to the classic FPS is the difficulty, prepare yourself to die a lot. This game is tough as nails, however, given the range of possibilities in combat  you will find yourself retrying the last encounter trying to find a better combination of weapons and powers that works better with your enemies. Actually, it makes it more satisfying when you finally wipe out a hellish horde of foes.

Technically the game runs great at 60 fps (some tinkering may be needed, look in the Steam Forums), offering lush sceneries with breathtaking landscapes.

In conclussion, Shadow Warrior remains throughout the game faithful to its classical roots while offering a very intense and rich combat. It has been one of most entertaining FPS I have played in years.

reviewText: The intro is just plain awesome. Seriously, even if you don't play the game it's worth watching. The sense of humor seen in the intro pervades the entire game, although somewhat sparsely.  That brings me to my main issue with this game, which is something that Bioshock Infinite struggled with as well - having combat sequences occur far too frequently and last far too long. The gameplay involving sword fighting and combat in general are great, but the endless waves of enemies quickly grow tiring. The good parts of the game would shine much more if only the combat was cut down a bit.\n\nThe story has a strong hook in the beginning but I eventually found myself not caring much after running around on a wild goose chase. So in retrospect I really should have just played the first hour or two and stopped there.

reviewText:
General Overview: If you hated Borderlands or Borderlands 2 because of its off color humor you will hate Shadow Warrior as the humor is beyond Borderlands - but if you can tolerate or even enjoy slightly immature and grin and bear it humor, then this game is a great one to play. Well written dialogue, a decent story, solid shooting, well done sound, incredible graphics and smooth game play make this a shooter that is worthy of the Shadow Warrior name as a reboot and if you like shooters this is one you should pick up.

TL;DNR: 8.5: A humorous over the top shooter, tons of loot, hidden secrets, decent story, great action and solid game play with beautiful graphics make this a shooter for those with a sense of humor and desire for lots of combat. Sound is great, soundtrack is fitting and there is never a dull moment.

Technology/engine: 9: super smooth execution although a number of loading screens that are placed in such a way as to not be annoying and keeps the graphical fidelity high and controls responsive.

AI: 8: Serviceable but a bit predictable but when the individual AIs of the mobs get mixed it gets intense and is enjoyable.

Graphics: 10: Gorgeous sets, great character models, wonderful animations, great cut scenes and great use of 2D cut scenes for memories. Flying Hog deserves high marks for the graphics used in this game.

Sound: 8: Sound effects are well done but occasional source to reception issues can be found in the game that prevent you from spotting the source at a longer distance. Otherwise its a solid ambient soundscape that creates immersion and adds to the game.

Soundtrack: 9: Great music throughout, I especially liked the unnerving heavy metal on the appearance of the black rabbit - one of the funniest and weirdly frightening moments that was totally unexpected in the game.

Voice acting: 9: Solid cheesy delivery and poignant when needed or appropriate.

Crafting: N/A

Customization: 9: Customization includes various powers, skills and weapon customization all of which are rewarding and make a difference in the game.

Game play systems: 9: Really well mixed variety of weapons and abilities and the game scales with a difficulty spike if you are just ripping through. A number of the fights almost feel unfair until you find a technique to deal with the situation and the tools are always there.

Controls: 8: Slightly awkward controls that are occasionally unresponsive or do something other than what was intended - ie D-D-RMB is supposed to heal you but will occasionally perform the RMB function of the weapon - which can kill you of course. Perhaps when it comes out for consoles it will function better (although I hate to play shooters on console - prefer mouse and keyboard). Other than that it functions well.

Story: 9: I was surprised at the quality of the story, the great use of humor and the still poignant tale that is weaved into over the top violence and silliness that really, somehow, works well.

Multiplayer: N/A

reviewText: A game with more under the hood than what it is credited for. Not only is it a blood and guts shooter swordplay hybrid, it is also a game which pays homage to the days of old, with games like Duke 3D and Serious Sam. Cheesy one liners, secret areas, half naked females, this game has everything that a veteran gamer could want. If you don't get this game for the nostalgia, get it instead for tight controls, well designed levels, good graphics and a stellar upgrades system. One of the best purchases I have made this year.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Best FPS I've played in a long time. There is no multiplayer, but the campaign is stellar. Plays like an FPS from late 90's-early 2000's, but with modern functions (sprinting, leveling/character building, etc).

Combat is phenomenal - between your katana, ki powers, pistol, SMG(s), crossbow, shotgun, flamethrower, rocket launcher, and demon bits (yes, you use pieces of demon as weapons. yes, it's as awesome as it sounds), combat is varied and exciting. There are probably an infinite number of ways you can approach any fight. The swordplay is pretty great - the lack of a parry  is a slight downer, but the ki powers make up for it.

The dialogue is drop-dead hilarious. Lo Wang's one-liners never get old, and the constant banter is what really gives this game its personality (IMO).

The story might be linear with not too many surprises, but if you can get by that and take this game for what it is (a throwback to late 90's shooters) you will enjoy yourself.

This is my first review ever, and until now I hadn't planned on writing one ever. Even at 10 hours (mine went a little longer after a bunch of avoidable deaths) for a playthrough, if I never played it again I think it's worth your money (or more, if you catch on a 75% off sale like I did).

reviewText: I was suspicious at first, could they recapture the charm of the original while also making it a bit more acceptable for the time (i.e. not hideously racist)? The gameplay is great, the character, though different, is just as great as the original, and it's, simply put, a fun game to play. There's not really much else to say, I'd recommend this whole-heartedly, it's up there with the classics.

reviewText: WHO WANTS A MORE WANG! This game is awesome! Run around as um... a ninja named Lo-Wang (we would get into the Japanese vs Chinese argument, but that happened when the game first came out in 1997*). You're out for revenge (like all good ninjas), and you'll take it via lead and steel. The voice acting isn't the cartoony Chinese stereotype it was in the original, but the facepalmy oneliners still remain. The graphics are outstanding, with lighting effects, and spraying blood in every corner. The ragdoll physics are pretty good, and the coolest part of the gore-fest that is Shadow Warrior is that you can slice up foes Kill Bill style leaving a trail of gore and parts through out the numerous scenic temples and bamboo groves you traverse. A rough patch I'd say is the controls, which get a bit floaty with numerous enemies on screen, but they work. All in all, this isn't Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon or Ran, it is Rage of the Master or Hard Boiled and it does provide a thuroughly enjoyable bloody romp full of interesting enemies and scenic locations.\n\n*If you are basing your views on the thousands of years of diverse, rich cultures that encompass half of the world's population, on a (very tongue in cheek) game, then you are indeed a sad person and should probably log out, get out more.

reviewText: I genuinely didn't know what to expect going into this game.  After playing the horrendously disappointing Duke Nukem Forever, I was fairly skeptical about this rebooted title.  At the very most, I was expecting a shallow FPS/FPK(First-Person Katana-ing) with decent action and an almost vacant story.  To be honest, I was surprised.  Shadow Warrior actually contains a story.  It's not particularly deep or engaging, but it is somewhat creative and the cutscenes were enjoyable.  The interaction between Lo Wang and the shadow realm demon Hoji ranged from annoying to hilarious, but I mostly enjoyed them poking fun at each other and taking cheap shots.  The action, however, was sublime - pure and simple.  Specifically, the katana was a pleasure to wield.  It sliced up demons and humans alike with noticable heft and precision.  The damage model for the enemies fit the game perfectly.  As the game progresses, new abilities for the katana and your ki" powers are unlocked.  These range from a brutal thrusting strike from your katana to a shockwave-like burst of energy from your free hand.  During the game
date: you will wield a weapon in one hand and perform "ki" abilities with your other hand (think plasmids/vigors).  Unless you are dual-wielding akimbo style
recommended: this is the format for combat.  This opens up the possibility for numerous different attack combinations and variations.  In fact
hoursPlayed: the more varied and aggressive your combat style
voteText: the more karma points you are awarded after each encounter.  Karma is used to buy skill upgrades to further increase your skillset.\n\nWhile the katana is the staple of your arsenal
helpfulPercent: there are plenty of other weapons at your disposal
votesHelpful: all of which feel solid and accurate.  Some are more effective than others
votesTotal: of course
votesFunny: but all have the ability to get the job done.  My only complaints about the weapons are that the fire-rate on some of them felt too slow and sometimes hitting the reload button prompted no response.  I would have to hit reload multiple times in order for the gun to actually reload.  The only reason that stands out so much is due to the rest of the controls being so responsive.  It wasn't a huge issue
commentsCount: but it was annoying at times.\n\nUltimately
column16: this game was well worth a purchase
column17: at least for me (sale for $11.99).  The in-house game engine produces some gorgeous visuals.  Texures look good
column18: as do the lighting effects and the amount of color is refreshing.  No dull brown and greys here
column19: well very little of that anyway.  That being said
column20: I would have to recommend this title.  It's an action-packed romp that delivers on what it promises
column21: unlike other certain titles (*cough* DNF *cough*).  I give Shadow Warrior 4 out of 5 bloody demon hearts."

Played the first part and it was pretty damn incredible and hilarious would recommend will update if it takes a turn for the worse but I can't see that happening - this ♥♥♥♥ is awesome and genuinely had me laughing a lot. (note this isn't a serious game this is a slash your way through an army of enemies with whatever you have - think DOOM as in that in story mode you can run around killing with whatever you want)
Negative marks it doesn't follow all video game logic such as crouching in a bush doesn't make you invisible, there is slight screen tilting when you strafe with A and D which is a little uncomfortable.
When you see the combo moves they look wierd but they are very easy to do and in all honesty the best way they could have done it since there seems like there is room for a bunch of combo moves.
The game does look pretty but you wont be focusing on that as you are sprinting / air dashing around flailing your blade wildly - you can cut off limbs.
If you want a good sword combat game this isn't what you are looking for - this game is for FUN.

reviewText: Shadow Warrior was a good game. An absurdly good game. I went into it expecting some decent combat and a really schlocky story full of bad referential humor. What I got was fantastic combat, a legitimately engaging story, and dialogue that was both natural and actually funny on its own right.\n\nConsidering this is a reboot of a 90s campy shooter ala Duke Nukem, I'm really confused by how awesome it was. It's easily up there with my favorites now.

reviewText: It's rather a relief to find an old-school game that got rebooted and they didn't make a complete mess of it.  A lot of the gameplay style is fairly old-school keep-on-moving-and-don't-stop" with fairly open levels (yes there is cover
date: but things like cars will work as much against you as for you if you're not careful)
recommended: AI that isn't that intelligent (often comes straight at you and only tries to flank at the last moment) and generally not so secret secrets (providing you take the time to explore the whole map.)\n\nFor the more modern player
hoursPlayed: you have the choice of whether/how to upgrade weapons
voteText: skills or even your katana abilities which gives quite a bit of flexibility in how you play. You can also use much of the scenery as a weapon e.g. roll barrels down a hill and shoot at them to make them explode or fire at abandoned vehicles to take out large groups at once.\n\nMy biggest irritation is the inability to fathom what's safe and what's not as there seems no consistency in how scenery is treated. e.g. on some maps
helpfulPercent: you won't find secrets unless you go for a swim whereas on others if you dip one toe in the water it's instadeath. reviewText:
This game is just plain fun. It brings back the early style of FPS gameplay mixed with modern FPS Gameplay and does it well. The guns are fun to use but the sword is the star in this game. Not to mention a nice level/skill system.

The story is also very intersting. I wasn't really expecting an actual 'plot' but it's pretty darn good. Though, there are times the gameplay gets a bit tedious, you want to finish the story.

The FPS community desperatly needs more games like this. This game took the idea of taking a step back and in doing so, LEAPED 10 YARDS. Hang up your military shooters for a day and give this game some freaking love.

The game is just a great big ball of fun. Worth every freaking penny. I really hope Flying Hog makes another game likes this.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
For fans of the older Doom-style shooters, Shadow Warrior will be a decent rush of nostalgic fun. The shooting is well done, with the action keeping a fast, flowing pace throughout. The weapons aren't as fun as some of the old style shooters, however, they're all fairly bland, with the katana being the most fun to use. The swordplay is surprisingly visceral, although you will sometimes slice through an enemy and almost nothing will happen, the enemies more often are either sliced to pieces, or react as if they had been hit by an actual sword. The story is coherent and interesting enough to keep the game together, but it's so tonally different from the gameplay that it often pushes you out of the experience. The two main characters do have a nice back-and-forth, with some of their dialogue actually making me laugh. The enemies however, get a bit repetitive, you fight the same 6 or 7 enemies during the entire game, and in the last few chapters, it finally gets a bit too repititive, and the combat stops being fun almost completely. The bosses are also fairly boring, Shadow Warrior doing the big impressive boss thing that telegraphs their attacks so far in advance you'd think they were trying to let you win, with the amount of health and ammo scattered around during these fights, they're just too easy. The ending is also a bit disappointing.

TL;DR: A fun rush of slightly repetitive violence with an okay story and a couple of interesting characters.

Edit: It's also fairly pretty.

reviewText: An excellent FPS. Linear story but there's a lot of reward for going off path and exploring.  The story is good and has some plot twists but the real amusment comes from the main characters snarky commentary. The weapon choices, and enhancements along with skill and power purchases make it fairly customizable and no weapon (aside from the flamethrower for me but even that can get a grenade launcher attachment) feels left out.  Enemy diversity isn't great but it isn't bad either.  The combinations of enemy encounters that they throw at you does escalate well and never feels too rediculous.  Bosses are well designed and nice to look at but the strategy for all of them is essentially the same.

I would recommend having a higher end computer (there's only so many blood particles a proccessor can handle), but the game is still functional with minimum  requirements. In short, the game has a few flaws, but with a little work it could easily become a classic, something our generation of games very badly needs. 8/10

reviewText:
Probably the best reboot of an older shooter to date.

Rise Of The Triad is more of a new coat of paint on top of the original than a reboot, which is fine (except for those stupid hitscan enemies and first-person platforming segments) but Shadow Warrior has almost nothing in common with the old game except the name of the protagonist and sword-fighting.

I want to say right away the sword-fighting is the best I've ever seen in a FPS. Most times I don't even bother with the sparse selection of guns because it's so much more satisfying to play with the game's simple combo system of pressing a directional key twice and then left or right mouse to use a sword attack or special move that knocks down or immobilizes enemies. Chaining together combinations will give you more points to use in a XP system for more moves, but will also make it more likely enemies will power-up themselves. It's a nice on the fly difficulty curve.

The original game was notorious for being borderline racist thanks to the protagonist Lo Wang's broken English quips. That's been thankfully cut out and replaced with some genuinely funny back-and-forths between Lo and a mask-wearing demon who follows him. And even better, a reoccurring joke fans of a certain Monty Python movie will love.

There is very little I can fault this game for – the shooting and sword-fighting is awesome, it looks nice, the difficulty feels just right, it's more violent than Peter Jackson's Dead Alive, it's hilarious, and there's a new game plus mode so you can max out Lo's skills and weapon upgrades.

FPS of the year 2013 right here folks.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is one of the most fun games I've played in a long time. Shifting around the battlefield slicing up enemies with a magic katana couldn't have been executed better than in this game, though I wished there was more enemy variety. The game has lots of guns too, but aside from the revolver I don't find them that enjoyable.

Graphically, the game is pretty good too, but it does lag in big areas with lots of enemies (although this is just my old computer hissing).

There's lots of easter eggs and secrets, and after every battle you will be rated on how original/good it was, so there's enough to do for the completionist.

Soundwise, it's pretty normal for a game. Somehow you can hear bullets impacting in enemies that are a hundred meters away, and other sounds are nothing special.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of shooters like Serious Sam and anyone who likes games with swords, like Chivalry or even Skyrim. The katana is one of the most fun weapons I've used in any game ever.

My rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior is a reimagining of the classic first person shooter by 3D Realms in 1997. The Story is a prequel to the original game. You play as Lo Wang who is ordered by his boss Orochi Zilla to get a sword known as the Nobitsura Kage. However obtaining this sword is easier said than done since you attacked by an assortment of demons on your journey. You are helped along the way by a demon named Hoji who tells you the sword is capable of slaying immortals and is anathema to demons. The dialogue between both Lo Wang and Hoji is extremely good and makes a lot of references to certain films and video games. The story is ok but nothing to brag about, it keeps the game going whilst telling a few jokes but it’s mostly forgettable.

If you were expecting it to be an old school shooter then you aren’t going to find this game. Instead you go from arena to arena fighting enemies and being scored. It can be more easily compared to Painkiller than any other franchise. You have a choice of nine weapons. Some make their return from the original game such as the sword and sub machinegun and some new weapons such as the crossbow and a double barrel shotgun. The sword is the best weapon in the game since it’s extremely responsive, visceral, powerful and just plain fun to use. The guns, whilst feeling underpowered at first do hold themselves up one you upgrade them by using the in-game currency which is just known as ‘money’.  The upgrades vary from giving you a larger magazine size too having awesome ones like upgrading your double barrel shotgun into a quad barrel shotgun. There are also certain skills you can acquire to give you more health, money, ammo, a new weapon, new moves with your sword and many more. Finally there are four powers in the games which vary such as healing two thirds of your hp, knocking enemies back, launching enemies into the air and making a shield to protect yourself. Each power can be upgraded to make them more useful in combat.

The enemies in the game vary from demons running at you and attacking you, protecting themselves with shields whilst shooting fireballs, flying in the air whilst shooting fireballs, rolling green goo and have it explode in your face and many more. You can also pick up body parts from demons such as their hearts which kill some of the enemies which surround you. There are also human enemies too but there extremely weak and don’t become a real threat until the last few chapters in the game.

The graphics are pretty good, there are a lot of different locations such as small towns too snowy mountains which all look great. The atmosphere and lighting effects are good throughout each level and fit the overall theme of the game.

Shadow Warrior is an extremely good game. Sure it doesn’t have a very good story and it’s not old school either but the gameplay keeps you engaged and makes you want to carry on playing the game. Highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of first person shooters.

reviewText: Not only is this a fun as hell and incredibly beautiful first-person swordfighting shooter, but the more expansive level design makes me wish other shooters took note. You can backtrack through pretty much every level, so you never feel railroaded into what the designers want you to do. Even though there’s no real point to it, I love the destruction. It’s an incredibly long game too, took me more than 25 hours for completion. I would never have expected such a deep skills system, but it becomes worth investing into when later on the game just dumps every enemy variety, gigantic or minute, onto you. The tougher the game gets (played on Hard difficulty), the more you’ll be switching out different sword specials, guns, and even demon heart/heads like a multitasking maniac.\n\nBeyond the gameplay and design that respects the player, it’s probably the funniest game I played in 2013. Great tongue-in-cheek references, fourth-wall breaking, hipster jokes, ironic fortune cookies, one-liners, and a well-developed love/hate relationship between Lo Wang and Hoji that becomes surprisingly emotional towards the end.

reviewText: If you are a fan of old school style FPS (doom, duke nukem, projectile shooters (not hitscan!), and one liners, this game is for you. Even better, the sword combat is stellar! You can practically play the whole game just killing everything with a sword (excluding some boss fights). Controls are tight, combat is fastpaced and the game runs smoothly at high framerate for me. Looks great on ultra if you can manage it! Flying Wild Hogs hit it out of the park with this reboot after cutting their teeth on Hard Reset. A shame the 73 metacritic score will turn some away from it. Don't hesitate to nab this game next time you see it on sale. The Soundtrack is also quite engrossing and badass, so get the deluxe edition if you can swing it. Get your Lo Wang fix now!

reviewText: This is an...okay game.  The direction on the humor is stronger than the delivery, and I think the same thing can be said for the gameplay.  The sword is definitely the most enjoyable weapon they have, and completely overwhelms most early encounters, until you get to specials that basically say 'change it up or get killed'.  Attacks, both delievered and received, feel like they lack weight, making it feel more arcade-y than I think really served it well.  The secrets are really well hidden, and sometimes things that are secret easter eggs...aren't counted as secrets?  Despite often spending quite a while on each level searching, I found I rarely got more than a couple of them per level.  I didn't jive with the combat well, and I don't think the game did a great job of communicating what it wanted out of the player (It was rare early on to get as many as 4 stars for a fight, even when barely touched and using lots of moves, leaving me feeling like I was playing poorly, even when continuing to win repeatedly)\n\nI may go back to this later, but at the moment pausing after raising an eyebrow at inconsistent reaction to water (Sometimes it does nothing, sometimes it kills you).  I wouldn't say this is a bad game, since it's not, but I think it's kind of average.  If you enjoy corny humor, it's got that in spades, and while the delivery doesn't back it, the writing is pretty solid in offering it.

reviewText:
This is an awesome FPS - It has cool guns, killer enemies (from demonic peons to skyscraper sized monstrosities), non-linear level design, secret areas, hilarious dialogue, and a plot that's actually fairly epic, told through artsy comic book-like cut scenes.

My favorite piece of dialogue (paraphrased):
Hoji: You know my name? You must be the chosen one the prophecy spoke of."
Lo Wang: "Really?! What else does the prophecy say?"
Hoji: "That the chosen one will believe any G**-D*** thing you tell him..."

I really don't understand some of these "professional" reviews on Metacritic. The one guy wrote that the levels are large and it's easy to get lost. Hello...this is called non-linear level design. It used to be that all FPS were this way. Now get off my lawn.

reviewText: There was a lot of skepticism surrounding the news that 3D Realms' 1997 shooter Shadow Warrior would be re-imagined for 2013, not least because the original game faded into obscurity compared with other Build engine games and was really remembered only for its often tasteless humour. Happily, Polish developer Flying Wild Hog went back to the original and rather than slavishly remaking it, did a wonderful job in taking from it what worked and removing or radically re-imagining what didn't. The end result is a hectic, gorgeous-looking shooter in a classic style with just enough of a modern sensibility to make it feel fresh. The most crucial aspect of the game's success? It has what the classic '90s shooters had and what modern ones very rarely possess - personality.

reviewText: A great way to describe this game, very simply, is with the word 'fun'. It's a blast. Gorgeous visuals, especially the lighting effects and a nice variety in level appearance. Great variety of weapons, which look and feel good to use. Plenty of upgrades, giving you lots of freedom to choose to how you want to power up. Lots of content too 17 levels and the levels aren't that short. Tons of secrets and amusing hidden easter eggs to find. Very nostalgic but at the same time very modern, for example the fact that nearly every little object in the game is destructible. The way the story is presented is a huge improvement on how it was handled in this dev's previous game, Hard Reset, and it's great fun to hear the banter between Lo Wang and the demon Hoji. Great game overall! (с)

reviewText:
What I expected
I've been looking for a modern adaption of a fast paced, oldschool first-person shooter, comparable to Painkiller or Serious Sam.

What I got
+
- Story: For a game of this niche the story is surprisingly entertaining. The basic idea: A man gets drawn into the conflict between demon lords and in pursuit of a legendary sword gets the power to not only save his world, but to also change the fate of their shadowy realm.
There are a couple of nice looking comic sequences in which the background story is revealed piece by piece, where your sometimes a bit annoying companion becomes a more interesting character over time. Not bad!
- Combat System: Fast and responsive. Melee is a big component and you unlock different swordstrikes over time. You have some magic spells (healing, stun, damage) and some enemies require different tactics.
- Character System: You have three areas to improve; skills, magic and weapons. Each require a different currency to unlock. There certainly is some room for individual choices so it's not just a feature without purpose.
- Presentation/Physics: Even two years after release, the game is still looking well enough. Enemies can be cut to pieces, burned or pushed away, some objects can be broken. The weapons feel strong and give a good impression of power in the game world.
- Sound/Music: Just well made. Weapons and enemies sound good, music is decent - a few tracks with asian or jazz influence are even good. Can't complain.
- Humour: It didn't make me break down laughing and did not send my sides into orbit. But still, the occasional Wang joke or light hearted comment was certainly good to keep the spirits high during the more repetitive moments of the game.
- Hidden extras: Join the old-school fun when looking for the most inconspicuous places. Exploration is well rewarded with money (for weapons) and an XP like currency for skills. Contains some references to the original game aswell.
- Difficulty: The highest setting insane" felt just right for me as an experienced gamer. Enemies are dangerous and you have to be on your toes not to be surrounded my smaller minions or charged to death by the dreaded berserkers. Still
date:
quicksave and the manual healing ability make every fight winnable. Even though you spend some time each fight just running away and healing yourself it still feels way better than those auto healing mechanics.

+-
- Weapons: Nothing really creative or particulary interesting. Katana
hoursPlayed: SMG
voteText: Crossbow
helpfulPercent: Shotgun
votesHelpful: Flamethrower
votesTotal: Rocket Launcher
votesFunny: Demon Heart
commentsCount: Demon Head. Each weapon can undergo at least one interesting change via upgrade.\n- Level design: Almost a negative point

Most fights have an arena like feeling where enemies are spawning until you've killed them all and the door to the next area opens.\n- Enemies: Nicely designed
column17: some require special tactics. They get repetitive over time though. A plus are the big boss battles
column18: although they all play VERY similar. Cool design though.\n- Characters: Not many interesting characters

which avoids mindnumbing stereotypes.

- Repetitiveness: Consider this as a huge point. Some areas really feel drawn out

thanks to the arena fights and repetitive level design. There have been a couple of places where I was plain bored.
- Bugs: I fell through the floor a couple of times and you can die when dashing down stairs. Minor annoyance.



My perspective
I've been pursuing this hobby since the mid 90s. My favorite genres are Strategy games

reviewText:
A fantastic homage to the original classic, Shadow Warrior is everything a PC game deserves. An absolute roller-coaster ride from start to finish. Definitely worth the asking price, and looking forward to more SW from Flying Wild Hog.

Pro's:
+ Fantastic game play, including gun play. The satisfaction the Katana brings is just amazing. SW has set the bar for fast melee combat.
+ Beautiful graphics, screenshots abound here. Fantastic amount of PC options for graphics, sound and gameplay.
+ Great variety of satisfying weapons and enemies. Slicing humans with the Katana is just therapeutic ;)
+ Feels perfectly arcade, just like the original game.
+ Checkpoints are placed at logical points, with the ability to F5 quicksave, perfect.
+ Fantastic one liners from Wang, in tune with the hilarity of the original, but not quite as good!

Con's:
+ I didn't enjoy the story as much as the mechanical elements, but it's still quite good.
+ A couple of weird bugs caused a save load here and there, sometimes losing progression, but nothing major.

reviewText: super fun and addicting swordplay is fantastic gets pretty hard but its worth it comedy is also super funny

reviewText:
I'm really new to the Shadow Warrior genre and I just bought it during a steam sale.

My first experience with the game and my take on it.

+ Astoundingly beautiful graphics.
+ Delicious gore.
+ Very original and cool weapon designs.
+ Lots of easter eggs, secrets and funny tidbits you can find when exploring the world around you.
+ Very fast-paced combat, always keeps you on your toes.
+ Wang.
+ Very nice artwork and environmental effects. Everything around you is a freaking deathtrap if you're not careful.
+ Very nice blend of horror, thriller, suspense and action.

Now for the cons.

- The head and weapon bobbing makes me a little nauseous. I wish there was an option to turn that off.
- The lighting in some are blinding and frustrating to navigate to.
- Some of the control schemes just don't make sense to me. Like the regeneration skill. Constantly pushing D" makes you move while healing

reviewText: This game has everything I'd want in a game amoungst the sea of copy-paste cookie cutter shooters we've become used too. This game doesn't take itself seriously, and that allows it to work in  humor and satisfying gameplay that will likely have me missing important meetings and deadlines. Diologue is witty and precise, self referencial and bizzare. It may be said that the maps are generic (as are the enemies), but it's wrapped up smoothly with smooth and easy to use gameplay and controls that makes cutting through hordes of identical demons a thing of joy. I would recommend having a higher end computer (there's only so many blood particles a proccessor can handle), but the game is still functional with minimum  requirements. In short, the game has a few flaws, but with a little work it could easily become a classic, something our generation of games very badly needs. 8/10

The demons in this game have multiple methods of death – Dealing with some is best if you shoot off specific limbs, others are best in melee range, and others are just best if you shoot them in the head.

The best part is the melee combat – If you’re okay with double tap action combat, this game is a great Melee FPS. Oh if only Skyrim had the sword play as this game did.

reviewText:
There are already a *lot* of good reviews out for this game, so I'm going to limit this to a bullet point list of think are the most important or that I didn't see mentioned in other reviews:

-A fun cast of characthers. This game isn't going to win awards for deep and nuanced characters any time soon, but as far as clever dialogue and witty banter go, this one's a winner.

-The swordplay in this game is what the combat in all of the Elder Scrolls games SHOULD have been, but wasn't. Your katana isn't just for when you run out of ammo - it's as useful and verstaile a weapon as any of the projectile weapons at your disposal.

-This game isn't just for b-movie fans with a love for crude humor and blood. The humor may *look* kind of sophomoric and racist out of context, but the game has very smart writing and it's willing to poke fun at itself. Most of the jokes in the trailers that seem crude or insensitive are actually, when viewed in context, a meta-commentary on the very humor the game it utilizing.

-The pop culture humor is perfect. It's clever and gives you sense of shared culture with the protagonist, rather than being heavy-handed and making you feel like you're being pandered to. It's Dungeons of Dredmor humor (hooray!), not Randal's Monday humor (blech).

-If you buy it at $40, you're getting your money's worth. If you manage to find it discounted to $5 like I did, you're basically stealing $35 of fun.

reviewText:
I never played the original Build engine game of Shadow Warrior, but this is what Duke Nukem Forever should have been - an awesome reboot bringing back the gameplay values of its era powered by a modern engine.

The implementation is a little like the Serious Sam series, but don't let that put you off if, like me, you're not a fan. It's a series of semi-technical combat 'arenas' in which you need to choose your weapons and tactics carefully so as not to be overwhelmed, joined together by explore-and-lewt sections, but Shadow Warrior seems to pull it all together a lot better than other games of the same ilk. The story is.. just ok.. for the majority of the game, but it rounds it out and sets the mood well enough to make it feel as though you have a purpose beyond go-there-kill-everything-repeat.

Not that that would be a big problem - the combat is immensely satisfying, with the game offering a large variety of ways to blow up, burn, electrify, perforate, and slice and dice the reasonably varied set of lesser and greater demons that you'll run into. You always have a few options on how to tackle a given situation, and throughout the game you'll be upgrading your sword skills, Chi powers, and less-up-close-and-personal weaponry to increase them.

The game also features a few boss battles which, although a little samey, make for a nice change of pace from the frantic melee of the rest of the game.

Hard difficulty recommended if you're a regular fps player - the difficulty paces pretty well, and by the time you're hitting the stiffer challenges of the later levels you should be good enough to whoop them if you've invested a bit of time in hunting down some of the secret xp-stashes that are lying about. Learn the special moves and make sure you've got your dodge key bound and you'll be kicking demon backside.

TLDR; had a blast - play this if you like to chop things up with a sword while listening to corny 'wang' jokes.

LO WANG / 10

reviewText:
This game is loads of fun. It brings back the feeling of old-school shooters like the classic Duke Nukem games. No waist-high cover shooting here. You'll be running and gunning against hordes of demons, all of which can be reduced into tiny chunks via katana, bullets, or explosives. Speaking of explosives, if you like killing enemies using the environment you will be very happy to know that there are plenty of explosive barrels, arcade machines, lamps, generators, etc. Another welcome classic shooter feature is secrets. Those who wander off the beaten path will find helpful items as well as retro areas that are a throwback to the classic Shadow Warrior game.

It's not just an old-school shooter with a fresh coat of paint though. There's quite a bit of character progression via skill and power upgrades, and all weapons have purchaseable upgrades, some of which make a fairly normal guns into something quite a bit more ludicrous.
There's also a system where each encounter is rated based on how stylishly you murder the waves of demons in an area. You get points via a score system similar to Bulletstorm's. Kills attained with different weapons and different methods will earn you a variety of bonuses. And the bonus you get goes toward upgrading your skills, so it pays to go for skillshots.
The health system is an interesting hybrid. It doesn't have regenerative health like many modern shooters, but it isn't soley a health-pickup system either. You have a demonic power to regenerate your health, but it's not passive. You have to activate it yourself and it only heals up to 65% of your max HP. Skills and powers can change how effective it is, but they can also improve what you get out of health pickups.

Most surprising though is how good this game looks. I wasn't expecting much since it's not a AAA release, but some of the effects and environments are really nice to look at. Another surprise is that there's actually a pretty decent plot amongst all the demon slaying. It's delivered in bits through chats with your demon buddy, and through above average quality animatics. In general there are a lot of little details that didn't really need to be there. Pressing the reload button with a full magazine plays a cool little animation, and a lot of insignificant items in the world are fully destructable.

The game has a good sense of humor too, and I enjoyed playing a shooter that didn't take itself too seriously. There are many wang jokes to be had, and the conversations between the main character and his snarky demon sidekick are pretty entertaining. The fortune cookies scattered throughout the levels all contain amusingly absurd messages too.

All in all, if you are sick of modern military shooters and want an over-the-top shooter where the final weapon in your arsenal is a rocket launcher, this is the game for you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior:

Positives:

+ The game features lots of guns, including uzi's, revolvers, crossbows, shotguns, flamethrowers and more. There's plenty of weapon upgrades which add everything from dual wielding to explosive rounds for your firearms. In addition, two skill trees are available which focus on improving your healing abilities, movement, luck, katana mastery and defensive and offensive Chi powers, such as knockdown stuns and damage reduction blocking. There's a great amount of variation here for character building.
+ Very engaging combat for the most part, keeping you on your toes. There's several different types of enemies - standard demons, warlords, shamans, berserkers, flying demons plus others.
+ Hidden secrets to find for those who enjoy a bit of exploration, along with the often amusing fortune cookies.
+ Graphics are absolutely fine considering the obvious low budget for the game. It's clear Shadow Warrior is not a triple A game so stunning visuals shouldn't be expected. It's decent and that's all it needs to be.
+ The game takes a good 15-20 hours to finish, which is not too bad for an FPS, hack 'n' slash style title.


Negatives:

- Weak story, limited dialogue, somewhat hard to follow. Very linear for the most part.
- Some non-sensical environmental mechanics, cars explodes by throwing shurikens at them, or a few bullets. Fighting is very arcade-like and lacks realism.
- Really tedious and boring boss encounters, which can take 20-30 minutes per battle (hard difficulty). Often they're not that hard, just time consuming and annoying.

Overall Score: 7/10

Shadow Warrior is a nice, action packed game to pass the time. It has an acceptable amount of content for a cheap price (especially on sale) so it's well worth it.

reviewText:
Shadow Warrior caught me completely off guard.
I hadn't heard much about it when it was released in 2013, and I hadn't really played the original from the 90s either, so when I acquired it as part of Humble Indie Bundle 14, it went onto my I'll play this when I get around to it list.

I eventually did get around to playing it - within the first five minutes, I was completely hooked, and this quickly became one of my favorite shooters.

Shadow Warrior is a story-oriented, first-person shooter in which you play Lo Wang, a corporate enforcer. The game begins as Wang is tasked with completing a straightforward purchase of an antique katana. Wang immediately sets the tone for the game by making cracks about the seller's henchmen and the cliché nature of the cherry-blossoms-plus-koi-ponds setting.

The combat system for the game is crisp and refreshing. Not only does Wang acquire a standard complement of FPS weapons as he progresses, he's also armed with shurikens and a katana. Via a pair of skill trees, one based on karma" (XP) and the other based on "Ki crystals" that the player can occasionally locate
date: Wang can learn special combinations (e.g. forward-forward-attack) that allow him to supercharge his katana attacks
hoursPlayed: or even partially heal himself. These combos add a dimension of depth and challenge to combat that helps to keep it interesting and intense throughout the game.\n\nThe level design is elegant and well-thought-out
voteText: directing the player without making her feel boxed-in and giving her the freedom to explore while still making it clear how to progress. The player is often forced to double back or cross her earlier path
helpfulPercent: but there's never that feeling of having to trudge back and forth across an area
votesHelpful: and there are often new surprises waiting in areas that have been previously visited.\n\nThe story is engaging but not heavy-handed. It's there to provide context for events and motivation to the player and the character
votesTotal: but the focus is definitely on the action - control isn't ripped away from the player every thirty seconds to show a cutscene or an on-rails sequence. The game is filled with comedic moments
votesFunny: and there's a steady stream of genuinely witty (not just "video game" witty) commentary from Wang that kept a grin on my face as I blasted and slashed.\n\nThe Linux port was very well done. I played from beginning to end on Ubuntu 15.04
commentsCount: and the game runs flawlessly on my aging Macbook Pro. It took me about 19 hours to complete the game on normal difficulty
column16: with a moderate amount of exploration and a few retried battles.\n\nIf you like old-school action shooters
column17: Shadow Warrior should be at the top of your to-play list!"

-Bosses were kind of lackluster and same-y. Shoot glowing points until weakpoint is revealed, then shoot weakpoint. Circle strafe while doing so. The spectacle made up for the gameplay with the bosses to an extent.

Overall it's a lot of fun, but watch out for those stairs.

reviewText:
This shooter has a cool setting and balanced feeling mechanics (including a fun melee system). Pick it up if you are after something a bit more old school.

A pretty game with smart level design and mechanics. Flying Wild Hog have clearly learnt from Hard Reset, this time doing away with the flaky weapon system and adding some cool melee and spellcasting mechanics to add some variety.

The awesome (but lighthearted) setting really adds a lot to the game, and improves a lot upon the dark and boring generic not-really-cyberpunk sci-fi theme from Hard Reset. Some talented artists have been given an opportunity to flex their muscles here, with some truly spectacular art (especially in the first level).

The melee and spell based combat system is nice, despite some strange key combinations needed to access them. The ability to heal means the game doesn't leave you stuck without enough health if you've missed a few health packs, but can remove some of the tension from combat. The melee system is nice and fits in well with the guns. You learn new moves as you progress, so tedium is avoided. But it can make guns feel less useful.

Levels can still feel very boxed in and limited compared to games like Serious Sam, and many of the secrets tend to be pretty boring. The guns can lack the authentic feel and kick you might be familiar with.

But otherwise, Shadow Warrior is a good effort at making more of an old school feeling FPS, with skill based, bombastic combat making up for most of the failings.

reviewText:
Originally saw this game on youtube as a part of a first impressions video, but for some reason it didn`t capture my attention enough for it to warrant its cost at the time. Boy do I regret not jumping on it at that time. Apart from a few dull puzzles and platforming sections, It`s definitely one of my favourite FPS game of 2013.

The sheer fun this game offers to someone who is a fan of anything Serious Sam -or Painkiller-esc. is insane. You get to carry up to 9 (if i remember correctly) weapons simultaneously, with slots 8 & 9  being hearts and skulls picked from enemies you encounter. The gunplay feels really visceral and the upgrade system is perfect for a shoot-em-up" game like this. Do you like killing tons of demons with swords or with tight gunplay? - Then this is the game for you.

But the strongest parts of this game comes in the shape of:
- Art direction - beautiful use of colors and Asian influenced set pieces and nature
- Katana sword-play
- PC features such as FOV slider which goes up to 120 if you so desire
date: a whole slew of neat    graphics options and no mouse accel. or smoothing. ("Praise the lord!")\n\nI will go out on a limb here and say that I have never been this pleasantly surprised when it comes to the feel and handling of a sword in an FPS setting. The feeling when you slice up demons and execute the katana special moves is unmatched in anything I`ve played earlier. The fast-paced movement system allows for you to feel like an actual ninja in first person view
recommended: dashing in and out of combat slicing up demons. It also opens up for you to "kite" enemies around just like in Serious Sam and Painkiller
hoursPlayed: which is a feature I especially appreciate during battles in the more open arena-style settings the game has to offer.\n\nI really liked the story for what it was
voteText: and it takes you on a fun ride through a variety of different locations and offers a good variety in scenery
helpfulPercent: even if its somewhat stretched through backtracking and puzzles. The characters are fun
votesHelpful: and early on you get to meet a really fun and excellently voice acted side character that will follow you throughout the game.\n\nThe humor in this game Is something I really enjoy
votesTotal: even if its juvenile. Hearing Lo Wang crack jokes during combat is a nice touch that keeps you coming back for more demon-slicing goodness.\n\nI would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Serious Sam -or Painkiller-type games
votesFunny: as its the best in its genre by far.\n\nLastly
commentsCount: I`d like to add that Shadow Warrior`s opening "cinematic" might be the best to date
column16: in any game ever!"

reviewText: WHO WANTS A MORE WANG! This game is awesome! Run around as um... a ninja named Lo-Wang (we would get into the Japanese vs Chinese argument, but that happened when the game first came out in 1997*). You're out for revenge (like all good ninjas), and you'll take it via lead and steel. The voice acting isn't the cartoony Chinese stereotype it was in the original, but the facepalmy oneliners still remain. The graphics are outstanding, with lighting effects, and spraying blood in every corner. The ragdoll physics are pretty good, and the coolest part of the gore-fest that is Shadow Warrior is that you can slice up foes Kill Bill style leaving a trail of gore and parts through out the numerous scenic temples and bamboo groves you traverse. A rough patch I'd say is the controls, which get a bit floaty with numerous enemies on screen, but they work. All in all, this isn't Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon or Ran, it is Rage of the Master or Hard Boiled and it does provide a thuroughly enjoyable bloody romp full of interesting enemies and scenic locations.\n\n*If you are basing your views on the thousands of years of diverse, rich cultures that encompass half of the world's population, on a (very tongue in cheek) game, then you are indeed a sad person and should probably log out, get out more.
